(input-box: bind $EBLEED,"") [[Submit Total|EBLEED Input]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 23</h1> Your vision blurs as you choke and gasp in the darkened prison where Loki is held. You feel your end approaching - a light rushing at you behind your eyes. And then the light is before your eyes. Frigga All-Mother, and Odin All-Father stand in the chamber, fully restored to their glory. Frigga speak first, "Stay your hand, Daughter. You are maddened with grief - let go these warriors and tell me of your troubled heart." "YOU!" Sigyn rages, "You have no say here! You showed by long years that you care nothing for my sufferings. You left me alone in the dark to watch my love burn and writhe without death. You watched Odin All-Father seal the cave. You shut your ears to my pleas, and hid yourself in the halls of Asgard, where my cries could not reach you." The accusation hangs dark in the air. Then the All-Mother speaks: "You are right, child. When Loki took the life of Baldur, my heart was grieved, for the most beautiful of all created things had passed and was no more. Grief turned to anger, anger to revenge, and revenge walked its dark road to madness. So it was with all the Aesgir. We bound Loki. But in binding him, we bound you who loved him as well, and remembered not that your heart was rent by his punishment. "I turned my back because the forgetting eased my troubled heart, but it was neither right nor good. For this I have been long stung by bitter remorse. (link: "Continue")[ Come, child, the answer to suffering is not still greater suffering. I will take upon myself the burden I had placed upon you. I have an oath I will swear: In the darkened months of winter, I will take your place at Loki's side, and catch the poison that falls. You will walk the Nine Worlds and have your fill of their beauty. You will taste Kvasir's Mead and eat of Idunn's Apples, and become lovely again. Thus I shall bear your burdens, my daughter, as you bear Loki's." (link: "Continue")[ Sigyn regards Frigga with suspicion. "How can I know your promise will hold, and by what right do you speak for all? This is surely a trick to lure me to the far flung corners of the realms and hide my pain there, far from my beloved." The All-Father steps forward, "My hand, too, wrought this terrible grief upon you. The prison was of my making, and the serpent's sting of my invention. I have been unjust, and so in this I cannot trust even myself. But to whom could we submit ourselves for judgment?" (link: "Continue")[ At this, the (print:$amulet) you wear around your neck burns. You remove it and hold it out, though it sears your hand. "When All-Father set us upon this quest, the favor of one of the gods was granted unto each of us. We know the twists and turns of this tale. We know the sufferings wrought upon the worlds and upon their master, and we now know the poison wellspring of injustice that brought all of this to pass. For this knowledge, and with their blessing in hand, I put forth the warriors of Midgard here assembled as fitting judge, standing in the stead of the realms we have walked, and of the realm we call home, and of the god whose symbols we bear. We will speak in their voices. Will this serve?" Each of your compatriots nods in turn, holding out their symbol as you have. Sigyn looks long at you, then replies, "I will accept the word of those gathered here. Speak your will." Frigga also nods "The All-Father and I also will be bound by the word and judgement set forth here." SIGYN'S FATE RESTS IN YOUR HANDS. CHOOSE! [[JUSTICE]] OR [[MERCY]] ]]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 24</h1> "You have done well, child. The undoing that threatened us is itself undone, and the World Tree is safe. I would reward you as you see fit: Would you lay down your arms and join the ranks of the brave and good in Valhalla? Gladly I would have you at the Great Feast of the Mighty! Or would you return to Midgard and take up arms against the slings and arrows of these wild worlds again, with my blessing upon you? What say you, warrior?" WHICH PENDANT DID YOU FIND IN TODAY'S CALENDAR? [[Sun Pendant]] [[Harp Pendant]] [[Flower Pendant]] [[Peace Rune]] [[Skeleton Key]] [[Snowflake Charm]] [[Shield Pendant]] [[Triple Horn]] [[Snake Necklace]] [[Moon Pendant]] [[Netted D20 Necklace]] [[Hammer Pendant]] [[Wolf's Head Pendant]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 6</h1> You set sails, and guide your ship out of the harbor and on to the familiar waters of the sea near your home. Though cold, the day is fair and bright, full of the promise of dawn. You wait for the way to be revealed. Then suddenly, directly in your path, the horizon tears from the top of the sky to the depths of the seas! A bright multihued waterway falls away at an impossible angle. The Bifrost is opened! The currents seize the keel of your ship and hurl it forward, like the waters of a great tide. The deck pitches and sways, and you are tossed like a leaf on a wind. The rudder swings wildly, narrowly missing your head. You dive and grasp it, desperate to hold it steady amidship, and turn the prow to the flow of the water's run. It strains and vibrates beneath your hand! THIS IS YOUR FIRST ABILITY CHECK! IN THIS CASE, YOU'RE ROLLING A CHECK TO SEE IF YOU HAVE THE SURVIVAL INSTINCTS NECESSARY TO NAVIGATE THE WATERS OF THE BIFROST! ROLL THE D20 FROM TODAY'S CALENDAR. YOUR RESULT WILL BE COMPARED TO A SECRET NUMBER (BETWEEN 1 AND 20) THAT REPRESENTS HOW DIFFICULT THIS TASK IS. IF YOU EXCEED THAT SECRET NUMBER WITH YOUR ROLL, YOU WILL SUCCESSFULLY NAVIGATE THE BIFROST! THIS TASK IS RELATIVELY EASY, BUT IF YOU THINK YOUR D20 ROLL IS TOO LOW, AND YOU THINK SUCCESS IS IMPORTANT IN THIS CASE, YOU MAY CHOOSE TO ROLL ONE OR MORE INSPIRATION DICE FROM YOUR INSPIRATION POOL AND ADD THE TOTAL FROM THOSE DICE TO YOUR D20 ROLL. THINK OF IT AS A HELPING HAND IN TIME OF NEED! BUT BEWARE - ONCE AN INSPIRATION DIE IS USED, IT'S USED UP! YOU WON'T BE ABLE TO USE IT LATER ON TO HELP WITH FUTURE ABILITY CHECKS. ONCE YOU'RE HAPPY WITH YOUR ROLL TOTAL, ENTER THE RESULT IN THE TEXT BOX BELOW AND CLICK 'SUBMIT'. (set: $Day6Number to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $RealmNumber, "") [[Submit Number|Realm Input]]The horizon shimmers into a greying dream, and the bright waters haze and blur into shadow and shade, all's lost...yet the rough wood of the deck beneath your feet still rocks with the motions of the restless sea. What far-flung world is this? A brilliant sun hangs motionless in the sky, its light so potent it makes the world glow. The air is warm and sweet with the fragrance of flowers that bloom perpetually. The sea is a sheet of polished silver, reflecting the endless light without a ripple. The breeze sings a soft, celestial music, a symphony of forgotten songs that lifts the soul. There is no crashing fighting sea, no acrid surf, no fear, no struggle, only an overwhelming sense of peace. This is Alfheim—the land of eternal serenity. ADD TODAY'S DIE (A D6) TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 8->DAY 8A]]Helheim - no sooner has your quest begun than it has ended in failure. You slouch on the deck of your ship, giving yourself over to dark thoughts. The darkness of your mind is dissipated in a moment by a luminous figure standing on the deck in front of you. "Be not troubled of heart, warrior. I and My Beloved have foreseen even this." The voice is Friggas, which rang in your head a scant few hours ago. Now she stands before you; great, and lovely, and gentle. "The Bifrost was not meant for the longships of Midgard. It was not our will that you should venture out so, but we were pressed all around by fate itself. Instead we have another task for you. This world, too, has the blight upon it, and the source here, as in other worlds, must be sought out. The way will be harder. Hel, who rules here, has no love for the Gods of Asgard. But as in all things, honor belongs to the brave, not for their victories, but for the merit of their striving against the darkness. Will you take up arms again on our behalf, warrior of Midgard? We still have need of you!" WILL YOU ANSWER THE CALL? [[YES->HYES]] OR [[NO]]The horizon shimmers into a greying dream, and the bright waters haze and blur into shadow and shade. All's lost...yet the rough wood of the deck beneath your feet still rocks with the motions of the restless sea. What wearied world is this? The variegated colors of the Bifrost are gone. In their place is the biting sting of a wind-whipped and leaden sky, and dark waves. Off the port bow, a desolate expanse of stony, heather-strewn moorland greets you, with the ancient craggy mountains rising like hunched titans. The air is raw, carrying the scent of wet stone and distant churning seas. This is Jotunheim - Realm of the Giants. ADD TODAY'S DIE (A D6) TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! A wasteland of scorched earth and black rock stretches three spans to star-wards, where infernos rage without end. This is Muspelheim— Realm of the Fire Giants. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 8->DAY 8M]]The horizon shimmers into a greying dream, and the bright waters haze and blur into shadow and shade, all's lost...yet you still feel the rough wood of the deck beneath your feet. A biting wind howls, carrying with it a silent promise of oblivion. Yet, beneath your feet, the deck is still. No waves disturb these waters. The silence is heavy. This is Niflheim—Land of Mist and Ice. ADD TODAY'S DIE (A D6) TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 8->DAY 8N]]The horizon shimmers into a greying dream, and the bright waters haze and blur into shadow and shade, all's lost...yet the rough wood of the deck beneath your feet still rocks with the motions of the restless sea. What far-flung world is this? You feel the pull of a gentle current beneath you. Dark waters stretch out on either flank, but you see the scarred stones of a bank on one side, and the docks and moorings of a bustling port on the other. Above you, cracks of luminescent sharp blue-white run through the cavern ceiling like lightning frozen in rock, sending a dull glow down on an endless plain of deep crevasses and rivers of molten lava, turned to the purposes of a thousand pounding forges and mighty furnaces that send a constant metallic echo rolling through the cavern. This is Svartalfheim—realm of the Dvergr. ADD TODAY'S DIE (A D6) TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 8->DAY 8V]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 8</h1> Alfheim—The home of the Light Elves, set aside as a place of peace and harmony, full of the joys and pleasures of the god Freyr and his people. Destroying this place would be a terrible evil - you must find the source of the blight here! To the NORTH The Luminous Woods - a forest of great trees lift graceful limbs to a sapphire sky. The leaves of the great canopy glow with an inner light. To the WEST, The Great Citadel - on a near shoreline, a great city stretches from the shores, up a mountain. At its height, a citadel of white stretches to the sky. To the SOUTH, The Sunstone Plains - A vast, open expanse where the ground is not grass, but a field of flat, golden stones that absorb and radiate the sun's perpetual light. The sky here is an endless, cloudless blue. To the EAST, The Singing Sea - a sea of silver beckons with its haunting song. ROLL THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D4) TO CHOOSE YOUR PATH! (input-box: bind $ADirNumber, "") [[Submit Number|ADir Input]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 8</h1> Jotunheim—The eldest of your peoples have said it is a Godless Realm—a place beyond the will of the All-Father and All-Mother, where life is brutal and wild, and the harsh and the terrifying meet and mingle so that none can tell the one from the other. It would be best to be on your guard. To the NORTH the land stretches off into a vast, wind-scoured plain of jagged rock. Great, dark cliffs rise in the distance. The way will be difficult. To the WEST a narrow pass winds its treacherous way through the mountains, quickly lost to view amidst the shifting scree. To the SOUTH the bleak horizon is broken by a sprawling field of colossal, fossilized bones and ancient monoliths. To the EAST the churning gray of the sea roars, and in the distant horizon you could swear there is the silhouette of a great, hulking form in the shimmer of the mist. ROLL THE DIE FROM TODAY (A D4) TO CHOOSE YOUR PATH! (input-box: bind $JDirNumber, "") [[Submit Number|JDir Input]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 8</h1> Muspelheim—a place of utter chaos, where the beautiful and terrible are one and the same. It would be wise to be on your guard, for here, even the air burns. To the NORTH rise searing mountain peaks their slopes slick and black with solidified obsidian, casting long, razor-sharp shadows over the ash plains. To the WEST a great fissure splits high dark cliffs to form a deep and blasted canyon filled with a suffocating, sulfurous smoke. To the SOUTH a river of pure magma flows, its slow, molten current carving a glowing channel through the land, each ripple a whisper of destruction. To the EAST a boiling sea of fire undulates. In the distant horizon, you could swear there is a shadowy movement in the shimmer of clouds. ROLL THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D4) TO CHOOSE YOUR PATH! (input-box: bind $MDirNumber, "") [[Submit Number|MDir Input]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 8</h1> Niflheim—a place of unmoving stasis, where the ice holds back the very passage of time. It would be wise to be on your guard, for here, even the air freezes your breath. To the NORTH stretches the wind-scoured tundra, their slopes slick and black with centuries of ice. They cast long, razor-sharp shadows over the plains of rime. To the WEST, the face of a mighty glacier is cleft by a deep narrow fissure, that extends to the ground. To the SOUTH, a fjorded coastline of pitiless mountains and cold inlets extends into the greying horizon, To the EAST a freezing sea of fog undulates, and in the distant horizon, you could swear there is a shadowy movement in the shimmer of mist. (input-box: bind $NDirNumber, "") [[Submit Number|NDir Input]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 8</h1> Svartalfheim - It is said that Odin shaped this land from the body of the first giant, Ymir, and set it at the roots of Ygdrassil. Maggots and flies that fed upon the giants body were transformed by Odin's will into the Dvergr and the Dark Elves, the two races that call Svartalfheim home. Craftsmanship of unimagineable beauty and power come from this place, but its people are insular and suspicious. You should be on your guard here! To the NORTH - The Deep Mines - beyond the banks of the river, you see great mine shafts plunging into the deeps, and the echo of a thousand blows of hammer and pickaxe. To the WEST - The City of Hamarsskor - A great city has been carved from the rock. Endless streets and by-ways stretch out to the edge of your vision, bustling with the sounds of commerce and life. To the SOUTH - The Canals of Svartalfheim - endless twisting and turning canals cross and recross, driving long low heavy-laden transports along in a ceaseless current. To the EAST - Nidavellir, The Dark Fields - On the far banks, a maze of forges and worktables stretches off into the distance, lit by the fires of forges and the trails of molten rock and glass. They flow down straight channels like fields of wheat in Midgard. Colossal works of iron and glass and precious metals loom: some hung by great chains, others resting on mighty supports as workers swarm on them like ants. ROLL THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D4) TO CHOOSE YOUR PATH! To the SOUTH the thickness of the waiting forest looms with uncanny stillness. To the EAST the green-blues of the sea undulate, and in the distant horizon you could swear there is a shadow movement in the shimmer of clouds. ROLL THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D4) TO CHOOSE YOUR PATH! (input-box: bind $D18HNumber,"") [[Submit Number|D18 Input]]You race back up the long winding way that brought you here, (print:$weapon) at your side, then through the alleys and byways of the city, heedless of friend or foe! Your steps seem to take on impossible length, and your companion's strides to devour the land beneath you into a blur. And in mere moments, a journey of days is behind you and you are standing again on the deck of your ship, it's bow pointed to Jotunheim's open sea! You hold your (print:$amulet) and call out to Odin to open the way to the Bifrost from the seas of this wretched world! And at your command, the slate-grey waves of the horizon are swallowed up by a twisting rift in the very air, and the mighty waters of the Bifrost roar forth, threatening to capsize your ship and throw you into the sea! ROLL A D20 TO ONCE AGAIN NAVIGATE THE TREACHEROUS WATERS OF THE BIFROST! You try to call out, but your mouth fills with the deep chill of glacial bifrost waters! You choke and cough, feeling the water invade your lungs! You need air!! ROLL A D20 TO GET TO THE SURFACE! (input-box: bind $D18VNumber,"") [[Submit Number|D18V Input]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 22</h1> As you emerge from the stairs, so do others from other stairwells - warriors of Midard tasked, as you have been, with turning back the blight. All turn to the Seed, and for a moment there is a deep pause, as all remember the words of the All-Father: ""Your blood must be the wellspring from which life will flow again to the World Tree."" [[CONTINUE->DAY 22E2]]A great luminous worm, nearly as long as you are tall, and thick as a tree trunk has edged its way up the bank from the water, and attached itself to your leg! You can now feel its teeth digging into your flesh, and the cold draw it is making on your life force! You kick it off in horror. It rolls away, and then by contraction of its body, leaps at you with uncanny speed! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! [[Try again...->DAY 21C]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 8</h1> Helheim - The eldest of your peoples have said it is a place of untold heartbreak, where the unremembered dead merge and dissipate into a sea of meaninglessness. A place where the sun never shines, and a cold mist lies upon all things. It would be best to be on your guard. To the NORTH the coast stretches off into the mists. A frozen sea churns against sharp, ice-covered rocks and inlets. The way will be difficult. To the WEST a narrow path wends its way through a forest of petrified trees, quickly lost to view amid the cold, tangled brush. To the SOUTH the trees of a dark forest stand in brooding silence. The trees are gnarled and covered in lichen. To the EAST the black-green of the sea undulates, and in the distant horizon you could swear there is a shadow movement in the shimmer of dark clouds. ROLL THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D4) TO CHOOSE YOUR PATH! (input-box: bind $HDirNumber, "") [[Submit Number|HDir Input]]a<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> As you sail into the wind and the land recedes behind you, the sea takes on texture. The silvery waves do not move across the surface as they do on the seas of Midgard. Instead, they come and go fitfully. Foaming wave-crests rise then disappearing. Ripples spread in wide circles, then reverse and converge and disappear. All of these intermingle with playful caprice. Sometimes the waters tumble over the sides without preamble, and wash in silver rivulets over the deck and back into the sea. You are soon wet through, but the water is pleasantly warm, and as it runs off of you it plays up and down your clothes like a living thing. It has none of the acrid saltiness on your skin that the seas of home have. Will you taste of the waters of Alfheim? [[YES->AEY]] OR [[NO->AEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You set your face toward the great forest. The light of the sun filters through the leaves above and combines in complex weave with the luminosity of the trees themselves, making patterns of living light and shadow that play on ground, root, and trunk. Soon, the whispers of the breeze change, and the massive, glowing trees draw closer and higher above. Their graceful branches seem to reach for you, and the luminescent moss on the ground shifts and turns to guide your feet. You notice as you wend your way through the light, that bright amber threads run down the trunks of trees. As you draw near, you see it to be the sap of these mighty trees, coursing in slow rivulets down each trunk and back into the earth of Alfheim. You touch it, and it has the familiar stickiness of the trees of Midgard. DARE YOU TASTE OF THE SAP? [[YES->ANY]] OR [[NO->ANN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You wander through this wondrous plain for a time, bathed in the mingled light and song. It is easy to forget the weight of your purpose here, and be drawn in to the perfect calm. The very air is thick with hope and peace. You notice after a time, that there is a regularity to the placement of the great willows and gossamer canopies. These are not a wild desert or plain. This is cultivated lands. The willows in particular are laden with fruit. You can see the threads of fire from the veined earth running visibly up the willow, through its limbs, and concentrating in long strands, like clusters of grapes elongated by the delight of plenty. DARE YOU TAKE FROM THE FRUIT OF THE WILLOW AND EAT? [[YES->ASY]] OR [[NO->ASN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> A tall figure steps forward. Her skin is a gentle amber color, and she stands a head taller than you. She is dressed in loose-fitting robes, bound practically to her body to keep them from impeding her movements. "Hail, Maor. We cannot in our memory recall one of your kind coming to our city, but we know much about you. Come, drink of the cup of welcome." She presents to you with formal grace, a two-handed cup of glass. In it is a bright-white wine, in which the light plays and dances. DO YOU PARTAKE OF THE WINE? [[YES->AWY]] OR [[NO->AWN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> The deck heaves and yaws beneath your feet as your longboat rides the waters. There is no salt spray to these oceans. Only the wash of cresting fingers and glimpses of a thousand thousand corpses that blend together indistinguishably. By and by, there is a glowing in the water's surface. There is a hand, that does not get lost in the myriad of waves. Instead it dips below, then rises again with a soft light in it. As you pull alongside, the hand opens. In it there is a brilliant white flower, set against the grays of the sea of dead. It is within your reach if you lean out from the deck rails... DO YOU DARE TAKE THE FLOWER FROM THE HAND OF THE DEAD? [[YES->HEY]] OR [[NO->HEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You wander for hours across endless terrain. Sometimes your feet find easy ground, and the path stretches out before you. Other times, the desolate ice-blown bluffs and sharp, craggy valleys hinder you at every step, making your progress slow and hard-won. You stop once where a frozen stream gurgles. Its dark, sluggish waters meet and war with the thick, unmoving tide. Their mingling is a cold, churning, with the black pulling and eddying into a deep, bruised purple in swirling, gray flows and ebbs. Your thirst is, by now, a bitter ache in your throat - your risk exhaustion if you do not drink soon. DO YOU DARE DRINK OF THE WATERS? [[YES->HNY]] OR [[NO->HNN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You set your face to the cold, dark woods. At first, the dim, light of the sky filters through in broken patterns on the dead ground, and the air is still. Soon, though, the skies disappear, and whispers of the trees change. Their limbs draw closer and tighter above. Their gnarled, skeletal branches seem to reach for you and pull at your clothes. Roots rise up to catch your feet. In time, all is dark, and your eyes strain to see between the trunks. You come by and by to a clearing where a great petrified oak grows alone. In its branches, a nest of carrion flies buzzes its quiet chorus of work around a great, festering hive. Your hunger, by now, is desperate - your risk exhaustion if you do not eat. DO YOU DARE TAKE THE STRANGE HONEY OF THE HIVE? [[YES->HSY]] OR [[NO->HSN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> Your way, at first, is easy and swift, following the trail of some long forgotten creature. But soon it fades to nothing. With every step you fight the gnarled branches and sharp thorns of dead undergrowth. Eventually you come upon a tangled patch of skeletal branches laden with small, bruised berries of a deep purple-black. Small, gray creatures with cold, quick paws cease their gnawing and flee as you approach. Your hunger, by now, is desperate - your risk exhaustion if you do not eat. DO YOU DARE EAT FROM THE VINE? [[YES->HWY]] OR [[NO->HWN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> The deck heaves and yaws beneath your feet as your longboat rides the waters. A bitter spray washes over the rail, and the bowsprit dips and pulls, fighting against the merciless waters. You are soon wet through, but where you expected the familiar sting of salt in your eyes, there is only a soul-chilling numbness. You lift your soaked hands from the tiller. This is not the sea of Midgard. What sort of waters are these? DO YOU DARE TASTE OF THE WATERS OF JOTUNHEIM? [[YES->JEY]] OR [[NO->JEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You wander for hours across the endless, stony terrain. Sometimes your feet find solid ground across a bare stretch of slate. Other times, the wind-blown crags and jagged ravines hinder you at every step, making your progress slow and hard-won. You stop once where a chilling stream hisses and murmurs as it wends its way across the broken terrain. The water is clear, and where it falls from a height, a frothing chaos of foam and spray is thrown up against the unyielding black rock. Your thirst is has become desperate, and you risk exhaustion if you abstain. DO YOU DARE DRINK OF THE WATERS? [[YES->JNY]] OR [[NO->JNN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You set your face to the endless fields of bone and rock. At first, the dim light filters through, and the air is merely cold. Soon, though, the whispers of the wind change, and the massive, fossilized bones draw closer and higher above. Jutting ribs seem to reach for you, and the rubble shifts and turns to trip your feet. In time, all is dark, and your eyes strain to see the way forward. You come finally to a small clearing, where a great, broken skull lies alone. Within its hollowed eyesockets, a soft, ethereal light pulses, and from the cranium, a buzzing chorus of strange, winged insects sing a strange quiet song of work around a great cluster of luminous, amber marrow. Your hunger, by now, is desperate - your risk exhaustion if you do not eat. DO YOU DARE TAKE AND EAT OF THE MARROW? [[YES->JSY]] OR [[NO->JSN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> Your way, at first, is easy and swift, following the track of some long-forgotten traveller. But soon the track fades to nothing. With every step you fight the shifting scree and jagged stones that slip and shift under you weight. Eventually you come upon a narrow crevasse where a strange crystalline fungus of a shimmering, toxic green clings to the rock face. Rock-like creatures with glinting eyes cease their eating and scuttle into the shadows as you approach. Your hunger, by now, is desperate - your risk exhaustion if you do not eat. DARE YOU EAT THE CRYSTALLINE FUNGUS? [[YES->JWY]] OR [[NO->JWN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> The deck heaves and yaws beneath your feet as your longboat rides the flames. The sides of your ship become blackened and ashed as you sail but do not catch fire. They are instead imbued by some strange providence with a resistance to the flames and heat. The bowsprit dips and pulls, wrestling your craft like a cat with a mouse. By and by the darkened skies open, and drops begin pouring from the sky. But it is not the rain of Midgard. Heavy black oil falls instead, slicking every surface, and threatening to coat you in a viscous cloy. DO YOU SEEK COVER ON THE SHIP, OR FACE THE RAIN? [[SEEK COVER->MEY]] OR [[FACE THE RAIN->MEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You set your face towards the base of the mighty mountain, which proves further away than your initial guess. Sometimes your feet find easy ground - a flat expanse of cooled ash. Other times, you're forced to pick your way over fields of jagged obsidian and through valleys choked with sulfurous smoke. Your progress slow and hard-won. The air burns your lungs with every breath. You stop when you see a great cloud of ash and sand in the distance, advancing on you like a wall that blots out the very sky. DO YOU SEEK SHELTER FROM THE STORM, OR STAND AND FACE IT? [[SEEK SHELTER->MNY]] OR [[STAND AND FACE IT->MNN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You follow the molten river for many hours. Presently it cuts through impossibly tall pillars of red rock that curve and arch overhead with a brooding majesty. At their base, close to the molten flow, the rock walls are dotted with hollows the size of your fist. Incredibly, small reptilian creatures appear and disappear, with erratic swiftness into these hollows. Some flounder and dive in the burning river. They seem to have no fear of you. One approaches and cocks it's eye up at you curiously. HOW DO YOU RESPOND? [[KNEEL AND HOLD OUT A HAND->MSY]] OR [[FRIGHTEN THE CREATURE OFF->MSN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You turn your steps towards the narrow canyon. The light the luminous red sky filters fitfully down to you from the mouth of the chasm high above. Your feet move through the low smoke, sending it rippling away. Sometimes the walls of the chasm are so close that you must force your way through - feeling the pitted rock pull at your armor and clothes. Other times it is blocked by masses of rubble, and you are forced to climb. The heat from the stones nearly blisters the skin of your hands. By and by the floor of the chasm widens, and you are astonished to find a wide pool of water. Steam rises constantly from its surface in slow curls. The air is sulphurous. Your thirst, by now, is extreme - your throat parched by the heavy dry air. DARE YOU DRINK FROM THE POOL? [[YES->MWY]] OR [[NO->MWN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> The water is preternaturally still, and the mist lays on it like a mother's hand on a sleeping child. By and by, from out of the grey horizon, massive icebergs emerge. They tower to impossible heights, forming unimaginable architecture. Soaring arches, and mighty pillars, carved with incomprehensible care dwarf your ship. You sail past most, sometimes close enough to brush your hand against their transparent skin. The air around them seems to distort at the edges. Or maybe that's a trick of your eye? You come eventually to the most glorious of them - a frozen leviathan arch, stretching a great span over the waters. The air beneath shimmers and wafts with the whisper of the unknown and unknowable. DARE YOU PASS THROUGH THE SHIMMERING ARCH? [[YES->NEY]] OR [[NO->NEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You wander for hours across the endless, snow-blown terrain. Sometimes the way is easy, and the satisfying crunch of snow underfoot marks your progress. Other times, the wind whips sharp shards of ice, cutting through you as it scours the stones, making your progress slow and hard-won. You stop once where a great river clogged with ice grinds in a slow solemn march thgrough the valleys across the broken terrain. Its movements are the deliberate sinuousness of a great snake. Your thirst is desperate, and you risk exhaustion if you abstain. DARE YOU DRINK FROM THE RIVER? [[YES->NNY]] OR [[NO->NNN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You wander for hours across endless terrain. Sometimes your feet find easy ground, and the path stretches out before you. Other times, the wind-blown bluffs and craggy valleys hinder you at every step, making your progress slow and hard-won. You see neither tracks from game, nor the leaves of bush or tree. Until, that is, you find a small beck running along a narrow valley. Along the banks, small delicate flowers raise their porcelain heads skyward. Their petals are jagged and black, and their leaves are a deep blue and crusted with frost. They are soft as fur to the touch. DARE YOU EAT THE ICE-FLOWERS? [[YES->NSY]] OR [[NO->NSN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You turn your steps towards the narrow fissure. The fog-laden light that filters fitfully down to you from the mouth of the chasm high above makes it difficult to see ahead. Your feet move through the mist, sending it rippling away in lazy sinuous waves. Sometimes the walls of the fissure are so close that you must force your way through - feeling the cold touch of the ice on your skin and through your clothes. Other times it is blocked by masses of fallen snow, ice, and rock, and you are forced to climb. Your hands and feet are soon numb. By and by the floor of the fissure widens to a wide cathedral of blue, grays, greens, and purples. Mist hangs on the wall's surface like an ever-changing tapestry. In the walls behind the mist, light makes shadows dance and move like living spirits. Waving the mist away, you stare into the brilliant depths. The dancing shadows seem to touch the walls opposite you, as if beckoning. WILL YOU TOUCH THE WALLS OF ICE? [[YES->NWY]] OR [[NO->NWN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> The waters of the canal are calm and steady, and you sail onwards. You try several times to communicate with the pilots aboard other ships to gain some knowledge of this place, but they ignore you, or shout epithets at you until they have passed you by. Your thirst increases as you sail on. By chance you see those in other ships dipping and drinking from the canals. You dip your hand in the waters and inspect them. In the low light nothing seems amiss, but you have no way of knowing whether they are truly safe for you to drink. DARE YOU TASTE OF THE WATERS OF SVARTALFHEIM? [[YES->SEY]] OR [[NO->SEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You follow the main roads downwards in hopes of finding some hint of the blight's source in this land. The sound of hammers ringing against stone is everywhere - a ceasless background cacophony that is oddly comforting. You pass gangs of miners often, some chipping at veins of brilliant gold in the walls, some pushing laden carts with straining muscles. By and by you see some resting in a small huddle, conversing low in a strange tongue. You draw their attention, but find that they do not know the tongue of Midgard. You communicate by hand signals that you would like a drink. One of them glances at you, then provides you with an earthen cup inside which you can see and smell a dark heavy liquor. DARE YOU DRINK? [[YES->SNY]] OR [[NO->SNN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You move in amongst the vast expanse of forge floor. Sparks fly indiscriminately, bathing the Dvergr workers in sharp light and shadow. The high pungent smell of heated metal burns your nostrils. In the hopes of finding a way forward, you begin asking the workers present for water. Most ignore you completely, but one grunts, and jerks his hand towards a waterskin sitting nearby. You pick it up an uncork it. A pungent smell arises that makes your nose burn. This is definitely not water! You see out of the corner of your eye that the dvergr who lent it to you is watching you speculatively... DARE YOU DRINK FROM THE WATERSKIN? [[YES->SSY]] OR [[NO->SSN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> By and by you pass what can only be a public house. Simple benches and tables sit in rows, and Dvergr sit in small groups here and there, quietly conversing with heads together. Dark Elves here are few, and they all stand silently waiting. You enter and approach what you assume to be the proprietor. He stares at you dourly, and refuses to speak in more than grunts, but he does at your request provide you with a clay cup, inside which you can see and smell a dark heavy liquor. DARE YOU DRINK OF IT? [[YES->SWY]] OR [[NO->SWN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> The deck heaves and yaws beneath your feet as your longboat rides the waters. The spray washes carelessly over the rail, and the bowsprit dips and pulls, as the waters wrestle your craft like a cat with a mouse. You are soon wet through, but where you expected the acrid burn of the in your eyes, there is none. You lift your soaked hands from the tiller. This water is not that of the seas of Midgard... DO YOU DARE TASTE OF THE WATERS OF THE VANAHEIM SEAS? [[YES->VEY]] OR [[NO->VEN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You wander for hours across endless terrain. Sometimes your feet find easy ground, and the path stretches out before you. Other times, the wind-blown bluffs and craggy valleys hinder you at every step, making your progress slow and hard-won. You stop once where a purple-blue brook babbles and laughs as it meets the tidal waves. Their mingling is a colored dance with the green and purple swirling in multihued eddies. DO YOU DARE DRINK OF THE WATERS? [[YES->VNY]] OR [[NO->VNN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> You set your face to the darkening woods. At first, the strange sun filters through in dappled pattern on the forest floor, and the air is warm. Soon, though, the whispers of the trees change and they draw closer and tighter above. Their knotted branches seem to reach for you and pull at your clothes. Roots rise up to catch your feet. In time, all is dark, and your eyes strain to see between the trunks. You come finally to a clearing, where a great oak grows alone. In its branches, honeybees sing their quiet chorus of work around a great hive. Your stomach rumbles. DO YOU DARE TAKE AND EAT OF THE HONEY? [[YES->VSY]] OR [[NO->VSN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 9</h1> Your way, at first, is easy and swift, following the trail of some woodland creature. But soon it fades to nothing, and with every step you fight the tangled branches and sharp thorns of foreign underbrush. Eventually you come upon a tangled patch of delicate branches laden with small berries of a vibrant orange. Small furred creatures with clever paws cease their eating and flee as you approach. Your stomach rumbles in complaint. DARE YOU EAT FROM THE VINES? (input-box: bind $DokkalfarNumber2,"") [[Submit Number|Dokkalfar Input2]](align:"=><=")+(box:"X=")[<h1>CALENDAR DAY 12</h1>] The heat of battle rage flows in you, but you feel the cold ragged edges of fear and pain pulling you towards darkness. You shake your head and rush at the creature with all the fury in your heart. With a great bellow you bring your (print:$weapon) down to cleave the creature in two and end its miserable life! It sails over your outstretched shield and digs its teeth into your shoulder. You cry out in pain, and feel despair take hold of you even as the creature does! You rip the foul worm off of your body and cast it aside. (set: $DokkalfarDmg1 to "0") ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! [[CONTINUE->Dokkalfar2]]<h2>MISS!</h2> You bury the head of your (print:$weapon) in the mud, and the leech turns and digs its teeth into your exposed arm! Your mind instantly clouds, and you feel the force of deep fatigue drag at you. You drive the edge of your shield into the creature to knock it aside, and it falls again to the ground, before turning and slithers towards you. Your mind darkens and narrows, only to snap back to reality. There is too much at stake! (set: $DokkalfarDmg3 to "0") THEN TOTAL YOUR DAMAGE FOR THE LAST 3 DAYS, AND PRESS CONTINUE! [[CONTINUE->DokkalfarDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It slithers at you, and all your attempts to repel it are in vain. You feel its teeth dig into your belly as your vision fades to darkness.. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands: Helheim. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[Continue|DokkalfarDMG]]<h2>VICTORY!</h2> You lift your (print:$weapon) purely on instinct, and by the glad hand of fate, the worm's assault drives it deep into their body. It is wrenched from your grasp as glowing life-blood pours from the wound! The cursed beast curls in on itself and screeches in fear and pain at you, which turns to a whimper as it twitches and jerks until it finally lies still. You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over and you've won! (link: "Continue")[ No sooner has your heart stopped beating, though, than Dvergr emerge seemingly from nowhere. They are stooped, gnarled, dirty, and move with a twitching shamble-walk - a sharp contrast to the rest of their kind. They approach with surprising speed, but ignore you entirely. Instead they dive at the corpse of the great worm you just slew, and begin greedily ripping at its flesh, snarling at each other like rabid dogs. You watch with revulsion. Several minutes later, the clatter of armor draws your attention away from the ravening Dvergr to an approaching group of soldiers. They shout their challenge, and the crowd of wild-eyed scavengers tear what they can from the worm's remains and flee into the dark. Soon only you and the soldiers remain. They approach with readied weapons and scowls of hostility. The commander of the group steps forward. "The harvest of Dökkálfar blood is a terrible crime, Maor. You will surrender your weapons and come with us." Faced with overwhelming numbers and already weakened from your contest with the luminous worm, you are quickly disarmed and bound. You protest loudly and at length, but are ignored. After several days of travel you are taken to a magistrate, who listens to the soldier's account with an expression of bored indifference. "All offenses related to Dökkálfar harvest are punishable by death. Take him to the pits and dispose of him." He says apathetically, without a glance in your direction. [[CONTINUE->SVA4]] ]They shuffle forward and attack with an unearthly battlecry! And as they do, the very mud of the ground around you turns against you, swirling up you leg, clinging to your flesh and seeping into your bones! You swing your weapon at the foremost of the approaching Draugr! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! (input-box: bind $DraugrNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|Draugr Input]] //The Draugar are corporeal undead creatures from Scandinavian folklore; reanimated corpses—often those of greedy or wicked individuals—infused with a malevolent power that prevents them from finding rest after death. These beings are typically described as having a grotesque, bloated appearance with blue-black, rotting skin, but they are not mindless; they retain their human intelligence, jealousy, and anger, and possess formidable supernatural powers, including superhuman strength, the ability to increase their size and weight, and even shapeshift into various animals or mists. Their main activity is to fiercely guard the wealth buried with them in their burial mounds while simultaneously terrorizing the surrounding community, bringing death, disease, and misfortune until they are destroyed, a feat that usually requires their decapitation and the burning of their body.//(set: _inputNum to (num: $DraugrNumber1)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "DraugrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 8)[ (go-to: "DraugrPASS1") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 8)[ (go-to: "DraugrFAIL1") ] [[DraugrPASS1]] [[DraugrFAIL1]] [[DraugrEatsYou]](set: _inputNum to (num: $DraugrNumber2)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "DraugrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 11)[ (go-to: "DraugrPASS2") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 11)[ (go-to: "DraugrFAIL2") ] [[DraugrPASS2]] [[DraugrFAIL2]] [[DraugrEatsYou]](align:"=><=")+(box:"X=")[<h1>CALENDAR DAY 11</h1>] The rest of the Draugr surround you, menacing you with their axes. (set: $DraugrDmg3 to "0") [[CONTINUE->DraugrDMG]](set: _inputNum to (num: $DraugrNumber3)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "DraugrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 6)[ (go-to: "DraugrPASS3") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 6)[ (go-to: "DraugrFAIL3") ] [[DraugrPASS3]] [[DraugrFAIL3]] [[DraugrEatsYou]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've fought off the Draugr until now, but their numbers are overwhelming. As the bring their fell axes down on your broken body, your vision narrows and fades to black. When you awaken, if it could be called so, your hands are one of a thousand thousand, cresting and troughing in the waves of the unremembered dead. Your story is lost in a sea of stories, mired in sorrow and sadness. A high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! (link: "Continue")[ But no sooner has the dust settled, than the mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[CONTINUE->HEL1]] ]You pick up the small flower you plucked and dried when first you fell in love. Its beauty, preserved from the moment of your union's beginning, reminds you of the lengths you would go to for the preservation of the beauty your union has brought. You place this memento into your tunic near your heart. ADD THE D4 YOU JUST ROLLED TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[DAY 5]](set: _inputNum to (num: $EBLEED)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die7") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 90)[ (go-to: "EBLEEDPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 90)[ (go-to: "EBLEEDFAIL") ] [[EBLEEDPASS]] [[EBLEEDFAIL]] [[Rocks Fall And You Die7]]<h2>DEFEAT!!</h2> You and your comrades at let the Eitr flow from your veins and into the tree, and for a time the colors mix and mingle and you feel hope in your heart. But soon it comes to pass that the pull from the tree finds no more Eitr to draw forth from you. It begins to pull your very life away and you feel the cold tingling numb of death creeping from your hand, up your arm, to your fast-beating heart. You crumble to your knees, but still the seed holds, and now the swirl of blackness mixes with the swirl of light. Jormungandrs poison reaches your fingers, then your hands, then your arm, leeching your strength and curling your body into serpentine agony. All is pain. A high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. In your mind's eye, you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> You and your comrades let the Eitr flow from your veins and into the Seed. The glow brightens and you see the mingled colors of the worlds flow outward and upward, into the walls of Ygdrassil. Suddenly instead of the rippled bark, there is a panoply of light and color, and the great reach of the entire sky appears behind the maze-dance of the heartwood's pattern. The mighty limbs stretch to the impossible ends, holding aloft the Nine Worlds, and where the blackness has crept insidiously down the branches, it is now forced back - burned and consumed by the combined Eitr of the Realms! The tree springs to life in a blinding flash of vibrancy and Odin's bellowing laugh breaks forth and suffuses all. The very stars themselves dance with the joy of new spring dawn! But your joy is interrupted by a swift and venomous pain in your outstretched hand. In your midst, a Goddess has appeared. She is beautiful and terrible beyond reckoning, and her wrath radiates from her in suffocating waves of heat and light. "NO!" She screams, "You will not take my vengeance from me!" With the speed of lightning she reaches and grasps the throats of the assembled warriors with hands that emerge from nowhere. "You ants and worms of Midgard dare to cross my will? I who have suffered twice for the transgression of my beloved? I will bind you with the entrails of your children, and bleed the snakes venom into your eyes myself, until all you are is pain and bitterness!" You feel your feet leave the floor and the air being choked from you lungs. Your vision darkens at the edges, and in place of the starred heavens, you see the cave under Jotunheim's earth, where Loki has suffered since the murder of Baldur. You blink, and you are there. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 23->DAY 23]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Your ship dips and wheels and the chromatic waves crash over you, sending salted spray over the bow. The waves catch the keel and fling it mercilessly upwards. Your ship founders in the chaos waters! You cling to the railing of your capsized ship as she is thrown down the impossible slope of the Bifrost, running and twisting between stars, with no hope of controlling your fate. You are pulled beneath the surface and your breath leaves your lungs. Your eyes close and your strength fails. Then suddenly all is still. You find yourself lying once again on the solid wood of your ship's deck, and you feel the gentle rocking waves beneath, but all is dark and greying, as in a murky twilight. The air is thick and heavy with rot and burning. You stand and look around. The sea stretches and is lost in a brown-gray horizon. The clouds are heavy and close overhead. But what strikes you is the sea: the waves that crest are not waves, but fingers pushing and grasping at the hull, and the smooth valleys of the undulating waves are made of the arms and legs and bodies of a thousand thousand dead. You have heard tale of this place. It is the world of the unremembered dead. This is Helheim. [[DAY 7H]]The calm, uplifting presence of the Goddess Eir stands before you, enveloped in an aura of soothing tranquility. A simple, silver healing band wraps her wrist. "I know of your task, Maor," she says, her voice steady and gentle, like a cool hand on a fevered brow, "and it will test you mightily. Go with my blessing. I will be a hand of restoration with you always and a wellspring of enduring health to you when your strength fails." And she places around your neck a simple flower amulet. It rests smooth and cool against your chest, absorbing pain and worry. Then she steps aside and gestures to your waiting ship. "It is time - the All-Father will soon open the way to the Bifrost. Make ready, and watch for horizon to split. Fair winds, Warrior!" [[CONTINUE->FrostGiant3]]<h2>MISS!</h2> As she lumbers toward you, your foot slips and you fall to one knee! Sensing your weakness she bears you to the ground, crushing you with her knee, and pounding her hand into your head. You throw your arms up to defend yourself, shouting a desperate plea "HELP, ALL-FATHER!" ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! (set: $FrostGiantDmg3 to "0") THEN TOTAL YOUR DAMAGE FOR THE LAST 3 DAYS, AND PRESS CONTINUE! [[CONTINUE->FrostGiantDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded your foe greviously, but not mortally, and she knows she has you now. She grins, and as her fist descends, your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, ""Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" The brute falls forward, growling her last anger at you, that turns into a gurgle. She draws her last coarse breath before lying still. You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over. You've won! (link: "Continue")[ The remaining assembled giants shift nervously, looking to each other for direction. They had not expected your victory. You stand and call out, "I come by the will of Odin and His Beloved, with a purpose greater than any one man or giant. You would do well to aid me. Take me to your king, or leave me be!" After a breath, one giant steps forward. "The names of Odin and Frigga carry no weight here, manling. But, we will honor your victory here and take you to the king unharmed." [[CONTINUE->JOT2]] ]In defiance you raise your (print:$weapon) instead and set your feet, staring back at her. "I come by the hand and the will of Odin and Frigga, All-Father and All-Mother. You should leave me to my business!" You reply. She grins at you with oafish amusement, and then plunges after you with impossibly long strides, shouting, and swinging her great club! Great ice shards protrude from his spine, glowing with Niflheim's Eitr. He could be a sculpture of ice himself, were it not for the breath that flares from his nostrils in mist, blue as the icy walls. His flat predatory stare fills you with fear. He has not moved, but his jowls flutter slowly, and you feel his deep growl in you bones, rather than hear it. You reach for your (print:$weapon) ever-so-slowly, praying you might retreat. But, just as you lay your hand to its grip, the great beast roars and leaps for you with stunning speed. You have only a split second to draw your weapon and bring your shield to bear! (set: $GarmrDmg3 to "0") [[CONTINUE->GARMRDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It leers at you menacingly, and as its jaws descend, your vision narrows and fades to black. When you awaken, if it could be called so, your hands are one of a thousand thousand, cresting and troughing in the waves of the unremembered dead. Your story is lost in a sea of stories, mired in sorrow and sadness. A high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! (link: "Continue")[ But no sooner has the dust settled, than the mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then a tendril reaches out from it, becoming an arm that wraps your throat with the inevitability of a snake's coils. A face emerges from the mud and turns milk-white eyes to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like judgement permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[[[CONTINUE->HEL1]]]] ]The ambient sounds of the mine shaft are soothing. The drip and warble of cave rivulets, the nearby sound of hammer and chisel, and the low conversation of the nearby Dark Elves lull your senses. Even the echoing distant clicks you cannot explain seem like a distant concern. It is only when the chink of hammers and the low murmurs cease, that you are startled awake. You hear the soft patter of hasty feet fleeing, and the clicking and tapping growing louder. Somthing is terribly wrong. You start and look up, and above you see the smoldering stare and great mandibles of a nightmarish creature, twice again your height, clinging to the roof! You heard the Dark Elves speak of this in hushed tones - A Gló-kló*! A tense moment follows. The great carapace of the fearsome creature flexes, and you see the dull glow of the creature's mighty claws brighten. Then in a flash it leaps at you! You have only a split second to bring your shield to bear, and swing your (print:$weapon) up! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! (link: "Continue")[ But before you can collect yourself, a colossal hand extends past you, grabbing the great dog by the scruff and pulling him bodily back on to the bridge, where he collapses into a snorting an whimpering heap. You follow the arm back to its source. A mighty frost giantess, greater in proportion than your mind can grasp stares down at you with anger and contempt. Her other hand seizes you by the leg and holds you upside down before you, hurtling you back across the void the way you came, where you slam with bone-shattering force into the wall. "FOOL OF A MORTAL," she cries, "DO YOU KNOW WHAT IT IS YOU KILL, AND WHAT YOU WOULD UNLEASH?" ADD THE D8 YOU JUST ROLLED TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[DAY 4]]You lift the armored girdle from the table and buckle it around your waist. Now you are ready! ADD THE D8 YOU JUST ROLLED TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[DAY 4]]It is as night falls that a shadow and a ripple catches your eye amidst the cresting fingers and hands of the sea of the dead. You watch again - certain it is another trick of your mind, but then it is there again. And then again. You trim the sails and tie off the rudder, leaving your hands free. Suddenly coils of a translucent, icy skin, and a spine of jagged, bone-white shards emerge from the deeps. You have heard of this creature: this is Gjallarormr, the decay serpent, who feeds on the sorrows of the dead! You cry out in fear and race forward, grabbing spears as you go! The beast bears down on your ship, and as it rises up to ram the craft amidship, its great head appears above the surface! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! (IF YOU CHOOSE, YOU MAY ROLL ANY INSPIRATION DICE AND ADD THEIR TOTALS TO YOUR ROLL IN ORDER TO SUCCEED) (set: $GjallarormrNumber1 to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $GjallarormrNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|Gjallarormr Input]] //Gjallarormr, The Serpent of Decay, is a terrifying entity whose very existence is sustained by grief and degradation. This massive, spectral serpent is said to inhabit the borders of the underworld, perhaps coiling around the roots of Yggdrasil or deep in the waters of Helheim. Gjallarormr possesses the horrifying cosmic function of perpetually feeding on the sorrows, regrets, and emotional decay of the unquiet dead. As souls pass into the afterlife, their residual sorrow is the serpent's sole sustenance, preventing the painful emotions from dissolving and allowing them to fester and fuel the creature's immense, dark power. (Gjallarormr is not a creature from traditional Norse mythology. I've imagined him as an creature of Helheim, based on a little research into the character of that realm)//(set: _inputNum to (num: $GjallarormrNumber1)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 8)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrPASS1") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 8)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrFAIL1") ] [[GjallarormrPASS1]] [[GjallarormrFAIL1]] [[GjallarormrEatsYou]](set: _inputNum to (num: $GjallarormrNumber2)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 11)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrPASS2") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 11)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrFAIL2") ] [[GjallarormrPASS2]] [[GjallarormrFAIL2]] [[GjallarormrEatsYou]](align:"=><=")+(box:"X=")[<h1>CALENDAR DAY 11</h1>] Gjallarormr dives beneath your craft and comes out the other side. You roar your challenge, and race to the tiller, turning to pursue it! Your craft is nimble in the water, and by and by you are able to chase it down and keep pace with it! You take a second spear, and as it surfaces you ram the point into the beast's exposed flank! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! The heat of battle rage flows in you, but you feel the cold ragged edges of fear and pain pulling you towards darkness. You shake your head and set yourself to the final clash. All rides on this - the last strike that will be the death blow for one of you. The creature rushes forward and you set your feet on the deck. FOR ALL-FATHER and ALL-MOTHER! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! For now, the strong wood holds together, but you felt, rather than heard her great timbers cracking. [[CONTINUE->Gjallarormr2]]<h2>MISS!</h2> You miss your mark, and your spear disappears harmlessly into the waves. The beast rolls in the water, sending your craft spinning. You are thrown against the railings, striking your head with crushing force. Your vision darkens and narrows, only to snap back to reality. There is too much at stake! (set: $GjallarormrDmg2 to "0") ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! [[CONTINUE->Gjallarormr3]]<h2>MISS!</h2> Gjallarormr rears up from the waves, intending to bring its weight crashing down on the ship, rending it in half! You throw yourself to the side as the creature's full weight sunders the railing and deck, though not yet breaking the ship's back. THEN TOTAL YOUR DAMAGE FOR THE LAST 3 DAYS, AND PRESS CONTINUE! (set: $GjallarormrDmg3 to "0") [[CONTINUE->GjallarormrDMG]](set: _inputNum to (num: $GjallarormrNumber3)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 6)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrPASS3") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 6)[ (go-to: "GjallarormrFAIL3") ] [[GjallarormrPASS3]] [[GjallarormrFAIL3]] [[GjallarormrEatsYou]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> The Beast, squirms on the deck, and you feel the keel of the ship rend in half. You are pitched headlong into the water. Your vision narrows and fades to black. When you awaken, if it could be called so, your hands are one of a thousand thousand, cresting and troughing in the waves of the unremembered dead. Your story is lost in a sea of stories, mired in sorrow and sadness. A high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! (link: "Continue")[ But no sooner has the dust settled, than the mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[CONTINUE->HEL1]] ]The silence of the valley is absolute, and the moon is a cold, watchful eye above you. Just as you are inclined to close your own eyes, you hear a soft scrape from high above. Above you, you see a gaunt, six-limbed figure against the moonlight. Its silhouette is that of a spider-like fiend, and its eyes glow with an icy green light. It speaks to you with a chilling whisper, a sound like blade scraping stone. "It is not often that prey comes to me. How convenient." And again it laughs, a dry, grating sound, then it leaps at you with needle-like claws! You have only a split second to bring your shield to bear, and ready your (print:$weapon)! [[CONTINUE->GjárúgDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It leers at you menacingly, and as its needle claws descend, your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[ You hear behind you the sound of assembling feet. The Dark Elves who fled at the approach of the Gló-kló have returned, and regard you with wonder. The murmurs of confusion and awe slowly morph to cheers and shouts of joy! By degrees you gather that this abomination has plagued the mines for many days. No attempt by the Dark Elves to slay the beast had succeeded, and the Dvergr who rule them considered the lives of Dark Elves to be a matter of indifference. The crowd grows, and as you pass all mining work ceases in favor of celebration, as you travel along the now crowded and jubilant shafts and tunnels. All celebration ceases, though, when a thunderous voice cuts through the noise: "WHAT IS THE MEANING OF THIS?" (link: "Continue")[ A troop of Dvergr soldiers stand blocking your path. At their forefront, a tall barrel-chested captain stares down the crowd menacingly. The gathered Dark Elves melt away into the darkness and you are left standing alone. The captain approaches and inspects you. "You've entered the mine without authorization, interrupted the work there, and caused a riot amongst the Dark Elves. [[CONTINUE->GolemDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've cracked the heartsone of the golem greviously, but not yet reaved the power from it It senses your weakness and bears down on you mercilessly. As its fist descends, your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[[[CONTINUE->HEL1]]]] ]<h2>HIT!</h2> Your attack shatters the arm of your foe! (link: "Continue")[ Before you can catch your breath, the rubble and glass all around take on life, rising and twisting into a singular, colossal form. The elements resolve into features, first vague, then clear and terrible. An arm of fire and rock extends from the mass, its fingers becoming a tendril of black flame that coils around your neck with the inevitability of a snake. A face emerges and turns to you: the awesome visage of a being made of pure, consuming fire. A voice speaks with the grinding sound of mountains shifting: "Who are you, and why do you trouble this realm. Speak quickly, for you have slain one of the guardians, and I would as soon break you as hear you." [[CONTINUE->MUS1]] ]You pull your Great Seax down from the wall and unsheath it. The thick angular blade glints wickedly in the torchlight, and its grip feels familiar in your hand. This will serve you well. You pick up your shield and turn to the wall of armor... [[DAY 4]]It is just as night falls that there is a shadow and a ripple amidst the waves that is altogether foreign. You watch again - certain it is another trick of your mind, but then it is there again. And then again. You trim the sails and tie off the rudder, leaving your hands free. In an eye's blink a mass of green and grey flesh bursts from the sea, with a gaping maw greater than the size of your whole ship! A Hafgufa! You cry out in fear and race forward, grabbing spears as you go! The beast bears down on your craft, and as it rises up to ram the craft amidship, one of its great eyes appears above the surface. (input-box: bind $HafgufaNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|Hafgufa Input]] //The Hafgufa, Old Norse for "sea-reek" or "sea-steamer," is a gigantic sea creature described in medieval Norse writings, often likened to a massive fish or whale. It was said to look more like a floating island or a nest of hills than a living thing, making it a danger to unwary sailors who might attempt to land on its back.//<h2>APPEAL TO A HIGHER AUTHORITY</h2> You grab Hel's muck-runnelled wrist and stare straight into her eyes. "You know that I come in Odin's name and on his errand. Tell me, O Ruler of Helheim, would you dare defy him openly? If the All-Father dies and all is lost, you too will be lost and consumed by an apocalypse that will leave nothing in its wake. If he lives and Ygrassil grows again, he will again sit enthroned as All-Father in Asgard, and you will join Loki below the serpent's sting. Choose wisely - it matters not to me."
