(input-box: bind $HCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $HCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die3") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 14)[ (go-to: "HCHARMPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 14)[ (go-to: "HCHARMFAIL") ] ]<h2>STRIKE A DEAL WITH HEL</h2> You step backward and away from Hel's muddy grasp, and say, "I have a deal to strike with you, Goddess of Helheim. You know I have the ear of the All-Father, and that I come by his will for the saving of all things. Your fate is bound up with his and with mine. Let us join in common cause, that Ragnarok might not come before its appointed time. If the World Tree should fall, all fall, and there will be none the wiser that we have struck a bargain. If it should come to pass that I and my kind should cure the blight on Yggdrasil, I shall speak with honeyed words to Odin of your aid in this. I shall see to it that in all of Asgard and Midgard, and the realms beyond, that your authority is recognized as a present and final help at the hour of need, and worthy of its place as a pillar of the nine worlds. Your wisdom will be carried beyond the borders of your realm, and your dominion will be set at the root of all things, untouched and eternal. What have you to lose?" ROLL FOR PERSUASION - LOW DC - Hel well understands a good bargain, and likes the idea of her reputation being improved beyond her realm. (set: $HCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $HCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $HCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die3") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 4)[ (go-to: "HCHARMPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 4)[ (go-to: "HCHARMFAIL") ] ]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Hel regards you with an expression of cold indifference that deepens into contempt. The air around her throne grows impossibly still, and the chilling mist seems to solidify. "You are a fool to bring the All-Father's pleas to my gate. He cast me out. He cast my brother into the abyss. Do you truly believe his will means anything here, in a realm, utterly beyond his reach?" Her voice drops to a chilling whisper. "I will not raise my hand to harm you, mortal. But my realm will. The cold of my dead will freeze the blood in your veins, and the very ground you tread will turn your heart to stone. When you can no longer feel, you will find your place among my silent subjects. Now go. Find what cold comfort you can amidst the forgotten dead." You scramble to your feet and stumble desperately away from Hel's throne room, your limbs already numb with the unholy cold. The vast hall's silence seeming to mock your every ragged breath. You are not running from her, but from the very air that promises to consume you, and you run not toward a living world, but only deeper into the bleak, unending emptiness of Helheim... [[CONTINUE->DAY 14HD]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> Hel regards you steadily for long moments, her face a stark canvas of flesh and shadow. "Come with me, mortal. You will speak in my hall." In a haze, Helheim blurs, and you find yourself in a vast, desolate hall of black stone. A frigid mist, smelling of decay, clings to the air, and you can feel the Eitr run through the very rock beneath your feet like poison through a skeletal hand. You sit at a table carved from polished bone and relay to Hel what Odin told you, of the failing of the World Tree and of your journey thus far. When done she sits a long time, deep in thought. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14HS]]<h2>GOAD HEL WITH CONTEMPT</h2> You bat Hel's wrist around you throat away, and find it disintegrates at your touch, then reforms at her side. You read surprise in her eyes, as you speak: "I need neither your patience nor your permission, blind little god-let. I fear no ending you might inflict on me. You are a small ruler of a small world, so wrapped in her own thoughts that she will be an unending source of contempt to all generations. No, I fear only that I should not take my place amongst the warriors of Asgard, and that The World Tree should die of the blight you well know afflicts it. Lend me your aid, or begone and leave me to my work, but don't waste my time when the honor of my house is needed by your betters for higher tasks." ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - HIGH DC - Hel does not appreciate being looked down upon! (set: $HCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $HCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $HCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die3") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 13)[ (go-to: "HCHARMPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 13)[ (go-to: "HCHARMFAIL") ] ](set: _inputNum to (num: $HDirNumber)) Process Input (if: _inputNum is 1)[ (set: $Hdir to "HNorth") (go-to: "HNorth") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 2)[ (set: $Hdir to "HWest") (go-to: "HWest") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 3)[ (set: $Hdir to "HSouth") (go-to: "HSouth") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 4)[ (set: $Hdir to "HEast") (go-to: "HEast") ] (else:)[ (set: $Hdir to "Error") (go-to: "Potato is not a direction...") ] [[HNorth]] [[HWest]] [[HSouth]] [[HEast]] [[Potato is not a direction...]]Suddenly and everywhere the voice of Odin rings, as it did in your head a scant few days ago. "Stay your anger, Hel. This one is here by my hand. You have surely felt the tremblings of the World Tree. You know as well as I that Ygdrassil's life hangs in the balance, and with it our fates as well. Listen to the warrior. They will speak in my stead, for my power wanes, and my voice fails at this reach." And his presence is gone. Hel turns her whitened eyes to you, "Speak quickly warrior. My patience with you and that witless boor grows thin." KEEP THE DIE (A D12) FROM TODAY FOR YOUR INSPIRATION POOL - ODIN'S PRESENCE IS WITH YOU! [[DAY 13->DAY 13H]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> You dodge and weave desperately between the heaving stones, half-falling, half running amidst the wild chaos. But all your efforts are in vain. Jagged rocks stab skyward, catching first your foot, then your leg, then your shoulder, sending you spinning on to the ground, your face to the sky. For a moment all is still. Then a great spear of slate rushes up, impaling you and lifting you high in the air! With your last breath you hear a high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the arrow of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> You dodge and weave desperately between the heaving stones, half-falling, half running amidst the wild chaos. By some miracle, you tumble into a wide cave a the base of a sheer cliff, where all is still. ADD THE D20 FROM TODAY TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 15->DAY 15DH]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Hel speaks truly. Sigyn must have some secret purpose apart from her knowledge. [[GO TO DAY 15->DAY 15HS]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> You sense a deception in the speech of the Goddess of the Dead. All has not been revealed. "Come, dread goddess, what more are you witholding? There is nothing left to lose here, surely" Hel's stillness grows heavier. The very air suffocating with the accusation. Finally she speaks again: "I have little love for Odin, and less still for the chains that bind my father beneath the serpent's sting. Gladly I lent Sigyn tears from the Weeping Stone for this purpose. But that was not the last I saw of her - she came again, saying the tears taken on her first journey were not sufficient to the task, and more were required. "I gave her leave to return to the Weeping Stone. What loss for me? I am bound here, condemned to guard the forgotten dead in a sea of sadness. If I could play my part for the chance to see my father free, it was a gamble I was willing to take. At that time, I could see no other motive in her heart. We are the lost and lonely - I count us bound by common suffering. Why would I refuse her?" ADD THE D20 FROM TODAY TO YOUR DICE POOL! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 15->DAY 15HS]]You consider the flower, then let it pass you by. There is no telling what the will of the dead might be in this realm. You see it fade into the distance behind your craft. PRUDENCE IS THE BETTER PART OF VALOR. YOU SUFFER NO ILL EFFECT! You continue on. The air makes your lungs feel strange. Slowly changes creep into the edges of your perception. Your ears are full of whispers that bleed slowly into your hearing, and if you focus, you can parse one from another. You hear the story of a mother taken too young from Midgard, who wonders for her children's fate. You hear the words of the old warrior who watched his sons and daughters sail for a new land, never to return. And to your awakened eyes, the sea is not the endless cresting of fingers, it is a sea of stories half-told, awaiting an ending unknown. Your fear of this world turns to sadness, as you sail on the stories of those gone before. THE EITR OF HELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 10->DAY 10HE]]You reach out and take the flower, and as you do you feel the root grow into your hand. You scrabble with the nails of the other hand to rip the flower from your hand, but fefore you can, your senses are suddenly transformed! Your ears are suddenly full of whispers, and if you focus, you can parse one from another. You hear the story of a mother taken too young from Midgard, who wonders for her children's fate. You hear the words of the old warrior who watched his sons and daughters sail for a new land, never to return. And to your awakened eyes, the sea is not the endless cresting of fingers, it is a sea of stories half-told, awaiting an ending unknown. Your fear of this world turns to sadness, as you sail on through the endless sea of the dead... THE EITR OF HELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. [[DAY 10->DAY 10HE]]<h2>EAST - The Sea of the Forgotten Dead</h2> Your ship heels starboard as you set the prow into the waves of the Sea of Forgotten Dead. The fingered waves crest and roll, and your craft is pulled out into the roiling waters. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9HE]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> "You will take Falki, my she-hawk. She knows the paths of the dead, and will accompany you, ensuring you keep to the boundaries of my will in this." Falki swoops into the hall and alights on the post of Hel's throne, regarding you with knowing eyes. She is beautiful and terrible in her stillness, and the Eitr of Helheim flows around her as the winds of a shadow. ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16H]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> A great she-hawk soars from the darkness and alights on a nearby rock, regarding you with knowing eyes. She is the might of the wind incarnate, and the Eitr flows around her as the winds of a shadow. You know this beast from the elders' stories: This is Falki, she-wolf protector of the dead. Her coming is blessing indeed. With her as your companion, the wrath of Hel cannot touch you, even here. ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16H]]<h2>INTIMIDATE HEL</h2> You grab Hel's muck-runnelled wrist and stare straight into her eyes. "Leave me be, Fool of a Goddess. I have no fear left for you. It is you who should fear: You know as well as I that your power is waning as the Great Tree dies. That fate opens like a yawning maw to swallow all, even you. I and my kind are tasked with the saving of Ygdrassil. Kill me or lend me your aid, but do me the courtesy of not wasting my time." You see all of life and balance it according to the scales of true justice. Lend us your true sight that we might know the true nature of the betrayal wrought on all of us. Odin and I have desperate need of your vision." ROLL FOR PERSUASION - MEDIUM DC - Hel would see through the flattery, but would like the idea of having Odin be indebted to her. (set: $HCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $HCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $HCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die3") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 8)[ (go-to: "HCHARMPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 8)[ (go-to: "HCHARMFAIL") ] ]<h2>APPEAL TO HEL'S HONOR</h2> You fall to one knee and recover your breath for a moment, before looking up and addressing Hel: "Odin, who gave you dominion over the dead, has need of you. Fulfill your oath that binds your realm to all others. The tree that holds all worlds in its embrace is slowly dying, and there is great need to find a cure. Shall we not all, like children of the cosmos, lend ourselves to her life, laying aside all strife for she who holds all in her grace? Look beyond your lonely halls, Goddess of Helheim, and lend your wisdom to the task, lest the Great Tree that bears us all should bear us no longer!" (input-box: bind $HCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $HCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die3") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 9)[ (go-to: "HCHARMPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 9)[ (go-to: "HCHARMFAIL") ] ]You consider the flowing waters, and though your thirst is mighty you steel yourself and move on. Only a fool would trust the waters of a strange land. You do place your hand in the waters, though, feeling the cold wash over you. As you do the waters curl up and around your arms, and invade your flesh. You try to pull back in panic but your are held where you are no matter your struggles! Your ears are suddenly full of whispers, and if you focus, you can parse one from another. You hear the story of a mother taken too young from Midgard, who wonders for her children's fate. You hear the words of the old warrior who watched his sons and daughters sail for a new land, never to return. And to your awakened eyes, the rocks and boulders fo the coastline are not full of dead stone, but of stories half-told, frozen in waiting for an ending unknown. Your fear of this world changes to sadness, as you continue on, bearing the stories of those gone before. The waters recede from you and cease to hold you fast. [[CONTINUE->HafgufaDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> The Beast, squirms on the deck, and you feel the keel of the ship rend in half. You are pitcehd headlong into the water. Your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the desperation of drowning you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" (link: "Continue")[ Suddenly, the bloody waters all around you grow and twist towards the shape of a body. The elements rise and resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it and becoming a tendril that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A voice speaks, with the low musical weight of power: "Who are you, and why do you trouble this realm. Speak quickly, for you have slain one of the beasts in my care, and I would as soon break you as hear you." [[CONTINUE->VAN1]] ]The mighty presence of the God Thor stands before you, radiating strength. In his hand, the legendary hammer Mjölnir hangs, vibrating with the latent power of the storm, and around his waist is fastened the mighty Meginjörð, his belt of power. "I know of your purpose, Maor," he bellows, his voice splitting the air like a lightning strike, "and it will test you mightily. Go with my blessing! It will guide your hand to be a crash of enduring thunder to you when your strength fails." And he places around your neck a finely wrought pendant, engraved with the form of Mjölnir—a symbol of protection and resolve. It feels solid and heavy, resting against your chest, imbued with the fierce energy of a coming storm. Then she steps aside and gestures to your waiting ship. "It is time - the All-Father will soon open the way to the Bifrost. Make ready, and watch for horizon to split. Fair winds, Warrior!" (set: $amulet to "Hammer Pendant") [[DAY 6]] //Maor is the norse word for 'person' or 'human' //The resonant presence of the God Bragi stands before you, his form imbued with the music of creation. "I know of your purpose, Maor," he sings, his voice a compelling melody that fills the air, "and it will test you mightily. Go with my inspiration! It will guide your hand to craft your own legend and be a wellspring of endless verse to you when your strength fails." And he places around your neck a finely wrought silver lyre that is his symbol. It vibrates lightly and resonates against your chest, humming with the promise of a glorious saga. Then he steps aside and gestures to your waiting ship. "It is time - the All-Father will soon open the way to the Bifrost. Make ready, and watch for horizon to split. Fair winds, Warrior!" (input-box: bind $HrasevelgrNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|Hrasevelgr Input]] //Hraesvelgr (Old Norse for "Corpse Swallower") is a colossal figure in Norse mythology, a Jötunn (giant) who takes the form of a massive eagle. He is said to sit at the end of the world, and when he spreads and beats his enormous wings, the resulting movement generates the wind and gales that blow across all the nine worlds. This action is the primary reason for the existence of the world's weather, cementing his status as a giant source of elemental power. I've imagined this creature to be one of Hrasvelgr's offspring - a mighty bird of prey that haunts the barren landscapes of Helheim //(set: _inputNum to (num: $HrasevelgrNumber1)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 8)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrPASS1") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 8)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrFAIL1") ] [[HrasevelgrPASS1]] [[HrasevelgrFAIL1]] [[HrasevelgrEatsYou]](set: _inputNum to (num: $HrasevelgrNumber2)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 11)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrPASS2") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 11)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrFAIL2") ] [[HrasevelgrPASS2]] [[HrasevelgrFAIL2]] [[HrasevelgrEatsYou]](align:"=><=")+(box:"X=")[<h1>CALENDAR DAY 11</h1>] The Death Eagle withdraws and considers you with animal cunning. Sensing and advantage, the eagle swoops down at your head and knocks you prone, then sinks its claws into your shoulder, ripping a deep gash. Your vision darkens and narrows, only to snap back to reality. There is too much at stake! (set: $HrasevelgrDmg2 to "0") ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! [[CONTINUE->Hrasevelgr3]]<h2>MISS!</h2> As the creature wheels toward you, your foot slips and you fall to one knee! Sensing your weakness the creature bears you to the ground, crushing you with its weight, and ravening at your exposed side. You throw your arms up to defend yourself, shouting a desperate plea "HELP, ALL-FATHER!" ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! THEN TOTAL YOUR DAMAGE FOR THE LAST 3 DAYS, AND PRESS CONTINUE! (set: $HrasevelgrDmg3 to "0") [[CONTINUE->HrasevelgrDMG]](set: _inputNum to (num: $HrasevelgrNumber3)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrEatsYou") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 6)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrPASS3") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 6)[ (go-to: "HrasevelgrFAIL3") ] [[HrasevelgrPASS3]] [[HrasevelgrFAIL3]] [[HrasevelgrEatsYou]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It leers at you menacingly, and as it descends, your vision narrows and fades to black. When you awaken, if it could be called so, your hands are one of a thousand thousand, cresting and troughing in the waves of the unremembered dead. Your story is lost in a sea of stories, mired in sorrow and sadness. A high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. The elements rise resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it and becoming a tendril that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you: the beautiful and terrible and entirely otherworldly face of a God who has been irritated. A voice speaks, with the low musical weight of power: "Who are you, and why do you trouble this realm? Speak quickly, for you have slain one of the beasts in my care, and I would as soon break you as hear you." [[[[CONTINUE->VAN1]]]] ]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> You pour your strength into the Great Fang, but to no avail - every vestige of will you have is spent. You slump against the Weeping Stone, and the white fire courses fitfully around you. By and by the poison cloud re-coalesces, and you feel yourself choking on the cloying air. Your lungs burn and your vision narrows! With your last breaths you hear a high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> You sing and sing until your voice fades to a whisper, but to no avail. The discord at the edge of your ear eludes you. You slump down to the floor of the Skaldsal, all energy drained from you. The cacophony returns, invading your mind and driving you mad with discord. The sound leeches into your bones and your eyes, until order is swallowed up in chaos! In your minds eye, you see in the arching sky the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> You pour your strength into the Great Fang, but to no avail - every vestige of will you have is spent. You slump against Mimir's Well, and the white fire courses fitfully around you. By and by the poison cloud re-coalesces, and you feel yourself choking on the cloying air. Your lungs burn and your vision narrows! With your last breaths you hear a high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Your furious assault finally cracks the vitrine, sending shards spraying over you! The great fang that it held is also dislodged and arcs out, falling towards the depths of Ginnungagap. You reach out to catch it, but it is far beyond your reach. It falls into the fiery icy depths, and as it does you see the blackness spread, and a great rumbling and shaking emerges from the roiling chasm. You hang on to what remains of the vitrine for as long as you can, but your grip at length finally fails. You fall into Ginnungagap, and the blighted Eitr embraces you like an enemy. Your vision narrows... With your last breaths you hear a high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Your furious assault finally cracks the vitrine, sending shards spraying over you! The great fang that it held is also dislodged and arcs out, falling towards the depths of Ginnungagap. You dive to catch it, but it is far beyond your reach. It falls into the fiery icy depths, and you fall with it. The blackness of blight spreads from the fang as you fall towards the roiling depths of the chasm. The blighted Eitr embraces you like an enemy. Your vision narrows... With your last breaths you hear a high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> The runnels of blackness burn up your arm, then your shoulder, then your chest, neck and legs, and still the great fang will not be moved! The burning in your flesh overcomes you, and you loose your grip on the fang! The waters of Hvergelmir sweep you slowly and gently into the course of the great rivers. Before your eyes close you hear a high uncanny laugh that echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> You pour your strength into the Great Fang, but to no avail - every vestige of you is spent. You slump against the walls of Ymir's skull, and watch the Eitr courses fitfully around you. With frightening speed, the blackness of the venom overtakes Ygdrassil's root. In your minds eye, you see in the arching sky the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> You pour your strength into the Great Fang, but to no avail - every vestige of will you have is spent. You slump against the Heartwood, and the Eitr courses fitfully around you. By and by the poison cloud re-coalesces, and you feel yourself choking on the cloying air. Your lungs burn and your vision narrows... With your last breaths you hear a high uncanny laugh echoes through all creation: of a madwoman now avenged on all things and the author of every end. Above in the arching sky you see the blackened branches of Ygrassil consumed as if the turn of time has been shot from a bow. Up and up the blackness travels, to the crown where Asgard rests. A rending groan runs through the World Tree, and the branches sag. Points of burning light, brighter than a thousand suns, begin to run along a million veins in its withered bark, that widen and strain. You can see them. The branches holding the Nine Worlds sag and slide and begin to dissipate like burning ash thrown up by the wind. A mighty crash, and the sound of every voice of every being that was or is or will be calls out in fear, and is no more. The tree splits through it's mighty trunk from it's tips to the base of every root. All falls. All burns. All is ended. All is dark. All but Odin's arm, which leans through all and catches the arrow of time, pulling it back again to the bow. Undoing become renewing and all is reversed, and you find yourself back in your bed, Odin's voice in your ear: “Come, sons and daughters. Gather to me, for I have plans and purposes for you. Come, rise and make ready before the dawning sun…” BEGIN THE STORY AGAIN! PERHAPS THIS TIME THE DICE WILL FAVOR YOU! [[DAY 1]]From what looked like a pile of loose, rime-crusted boulders, three great humanoid figure rises! They are twice your height, and clad in plates of darkened ice and rough-hammered metal. Their skin beneath is the grey of bedrock. Their movements are slow and deliberate, and appear to you blurred, as if they do not move through the air as you do, but force their great bodies to slide forward through time. You ready your (print:$weapon), and as one ice giants lumber forward, you dodge to one side and swing! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! [[CONTINUE->IceGiantDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've survived the onslaught, and wounded your opponents but not mortally, and the remaining giants sense your weakness. They bear down on you mercilessly, and as their weapons descend to end you, your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" Those that remain alive, immediately bend the knee in submission. You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over. You've won! But no sooner has your heart stopped beating, than the very air is rent by a great sourceless voice, that echoes through you with inevitability. "WHY DO YOU ATTACK THE GUARDIANS OF THIS REALM?" (link: "Continue")[ The light of day is suddenly extinguished. Dark descends like a curtain, blurring colors downwards from the crown of the sky. Time around you slows altogether. The dark is alive. A moving, nebulous mass of shadow, rises and twists into a singular, colossal form. The shadow resolves into features, first vague, then clear and beautiful and terrible. A dress of living blackness swirls and blurs up a graceful form, to deep dark skin, and burning eyes. The great form of Nott, Goddess of the Night, leans towards you. Her voice moves through you as easily as a cold wind. "SPEAK YOUR PIECE, MAOR. SPEAK OR DIE." [[CONTINUE->NIF1]] ]<h2>APPEAL TO A HIGHER AUTHORITY</h2> You stand tall, and hold Thrym's eyes as you begin to speak: "Hail, King of the Giants. I come in the name of the All-Father, who bested your forefather, Ymir, and whose hands shaped the nine worlds. All authority is his, and we both live and rule at his pleasure. I come to invoke the oath to which your very life binds you - an oath to the All-Father and All-Mother. Tell me, King of Jotunheim, would you dare defy the will of the king of all creation? You owe him your allegiance. If the tree dies and all is consumed by the primordial chaos that lies beyond, you too will be torn apart and swallowed. But if it lives, and Yggdrasil grows again, you will have to answer for your broken oath. Choose wisely—it matters not to me." ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - HIGH DC - Thrym doesn't recognize Odin's authority, and indeed resents it. Nor does he like they way you've spoken to him as an equal. "Hail, King of Giants. I come by Odin's hand, but my will is my own. This blight comes by the folly of the All-Father and his ilk, a consequence of his arrogance, and a testament to his waning power. The tree's fate is not a threat to you, but an opportunity. An opportunity to prove that you and your kind are not just survivors, but masters of this coming new age. He has sent me on this quest but mistaken me for an ally. My will is to use his weakness to hasten his downfall, and raise up Midgard to where he once stood. If you would join me, I will gladly join the strength of Jotunheim to the hardiness of Midgard." "What say you, King of Jotunheim?" "I owe you no answer, Thrym. I have no fear left for you. It is your ignorance I pity: You swagger about, believing you are a master of this coming age, but you are a fool to think yourself so apart from the very world you stand upon. Perhaps you believe the Great Tree’s demise is a victory. You are a fool. The very air you breathe, the rock beneath your feet, is born of its lifeblood. The fate you embrace like a lover opens like a yawning maw to swallow all, even you, as your world is ripped to shreds along with his." "Kill me, or lend me your aid. This is a foolish trick, and you are a fool for trying it." "Flee, vermin. Go back to your hovel. I'll grant you a hundred steps before I sound the hunting horn." "Run and hide. Call the Old Man in the Sky to save your skin if you wish. He won't." You turn, and race desperately away from the great hall and into the darkness around you, not knowing where you are or where to go. Your only thought is flight into the dark streets of the City of Giants. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14JD]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> Thyrm regards you steadily for long moments, before speaking "Come with me, manling. We will speak in private." Thrym leads you to an antechamber and sits, pouring himself a goblet of wine. "You have courage, small one. That I can respect. Tell me what plagues the World Tree. I will listen." You sit at table, and relay to Thrym what Odin told you, of the failing of the World Tree, and of your journey thus far. When done he sits a long time, deep in thought. Only a fool trusts to strange seas for favor. PRUDENCE IS THE BETTER PART OF VALOR: ADD THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D12) TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL, TO USE IN AID OF A FUTURE TASK OF YOUR CHOOSING! You continue on into the grim grey wilderness of Jotunheim. The air is cold and damp, and makes your lungs feel heavy. Slowly changes creep into the edges of your perception. Your awareness broadens. You feel the slow coursing of cold through the bedrock. The echoes of immense footfalls left on the stones. The shadow of brooding menace colors every valley and on every peak. THE EITR OF JOTUNHEIM, THE BITTER HARDENED POWER OF THE PRIMORDIAL WORLD, DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. [[DAY 10->DAY 10JE]]You regard the water running down your hand, and raise it to your lips with no small fear. It's taste is unworldly and bitter and cold as stone. Your limbs are suffused with a profound, bone-deep cold, but your life is not threatened. Instead it is as if the scales fall from your eyes, your vision awakened. You feel the slow coursing of cold through the bedrock of the sea floor. You see the wending trails of immense, shadowy forms beneath, and the wind above shifting like mighty waves in the sky. THE EITR OF JOTUNHEIM, THE BITTER HARDENED POWER OF THE PRIMORDIAL WORLD, DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. [[DAY 10->DAY 10JE]]<h2>EAST - The Grey Sea</h2> Your ship heels starboard as you set the prow into the waves of this Jotunheim Sea. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9JE]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> From a high, dark crevice in the hall's ceiling, a great she-hawk descends in a silent, powerful glide. She lands on his forearm and regards you with piercing, unblinking eyes. Eitr, cold and luminous, swirls around her in a whirlwind of mist. "Here, take Falki with you," he says. "She will lead you to Mimir's Well, and let my people know to leave you be." ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16JT]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> From a high, dark crevice in the hovel's ceiling, a great she-hawk descends in a silent, powerful glide. "She will lead you to my well, and keep you safe from Thrym's overreach." ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16JM]]<h2>INTIMIDATE THRYM</h2> You stare back boldly at the King of the Giants. "Leave me be, Thrym. I have no fear left for you. It is you who should fear: You may believe Odin’s power is waning, but I tell you his fury is building, and his wrath will find its mark in this realm of yours. I know you sense Ygdrassil's failing. Perhaps you think the tree’s demise a victory...You are a fool. You know as well as I that its roots are buried deep within your earth. Fate opens like a yawning maw to swallow all, even you, as your world is ripped to shreds along with his." "I and my kind are tasked with the saving of Yggdrasil. Kill me or lend me your aid." ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - LOW DC - Thrym is impressed by your brazen boldness, and the conviction of your words. He might believe that you speak the truth. (set: $JCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $JCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $JCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 5)[ (go-to: "JCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 5)[ (go-to: "JCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>MANIPULATE THRYM BY FLATTERY</h2> You sink to one knee in respect, before looking up and addressing Thrym. "Hail Thrym, mightiest of Giants. In my world, O King, you and your world are called the Godless Realm - a place of unyielding stone and brutal might, beyond the reckoning of the Aesgir. You see where Odin could not, and I have desperate need of your cunning for the saving of the world tree." "Help us, and your name will be remembered for all time, a legend of strength that even the All-Father could not command." ROLL FOR PERSUASION - LOW DC - Thrym is vain and arrogant enough to believe himself Odin's equal, and loves hearing it from others.. (set: $JCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! "Hail Thrym, mightiest of Giants. I come to you with a matter of honor, the honor of a king who commands the respect of all he touches. The blight that festers in the roots of the World Tree is a plague upon the very cosmos, and it is a vile and cowardly thing to let it spread. "Ygdrassil, which holds all worlds is slowly dying. Shall we not all, like sons and daughters, lend ourselves to her life? Unbend your pride, King of Jotunheim, and lend your strength to the task, lest the Great Tree that bore us all should bear us no longer!" [[DAY 10->DAY 10JN]]<h2>NORTH - The Wind-Scoured Plain</h2> You swing the tiller landward, and your ship heels to your turn. You find a small cove where the water is calm, and beach your craft there. The wind whispers and moans over the bluffs, calling you, or warning you onwards. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9JN]]<h2>JOIN THE MIGHTY IN VALHALLA</h2> The Eitr you carry in your bloodstream flows from you to the World Tree, and passed on to the heart of another; a warrior who will one day soon answer Odin All-Father's call and follow in the footsteps of the hero! You, though, pass beyond mortal life, and find yourself at the steps of Vahalla. The great warriors of old hail you as friend, and you sit at the feast of the mighty! GIVE YOUR FAVORITE DIE AWAY TO YOUR BELOVED (SIGNIFICANT OTHER, CLOSE FRIEND, FAMILY), FOR THEIR NEXT DND CAMPAIGN! [[CONTINUE->THANKYOU]]Suddenly and everywhere the voice of Odin rings, as it did in your head a scant few days ago. "Stay your hand, worms. This one is here by my hand, and should you harm him I will reave the life from you with my spear where you stand. You will take him to Thrym and give him leave to speak. This is our will." And with that his voice is gone. Reluctantly, the assembled giants gather, and form a cold and silent escort. Any questions are rebuffed with silence are grunts of indifference. They take you on a long day's travel across the lands and seas of Jotunheim, to a great city you know of only from legend: Utgard. The great city of Utgard is a testament to the might and grim purpose of the giants. Its colossal halls carved from the black, jagged heart of Jotunheim's mountains. Here, no sun warms the sky, and no star shines through the perpetual, storm-torn clouds. There is only the raw, bone-chilling cold that is the true breath of this world. (link: "Continue...")[ You are taken immediately to the court of Thrym, who rules Jotunheim with an iron fist. He is a mountainous figure, even amongst the Jötnar, his immense form clad in the raw hides of beasts and the black iron of Jotunheim's depths. He radiates brutal power, brazen arrogance, and low cunning. He is said to have stolen the hammer Mjollnir from Thor's hand once, and kept it in this world for a fleeting moment before being humbled by the Thunder God. "So," He grinds from his throne, "Who are you and what's your business in my realm? Speak quickly warrior. You're more fun for me gutted than gabbing." [[DAY 10->DAY 10JS]]You reach slowly and carefully into the empty socket of the skull, and with only a few bites of chilling pain from the insects around, you manage to retrieve a handful of amber marrow from the skull. It is viscous, and glows with its own cold light. It tastes of immense age, with a faint metallic tang. As you consume it, in an instant your mind awakens, and you feel the coursing of cold through the bedrock. The echoes of immense footfalls left on the stones. The weight of the world on every valley and on every peak. THE EITR OF JOTUNHEIM, THE BITTER HARDENED POWER OF THE PRIMORDIAL WORLD, DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. [[DAY 10->DAY 10JS]]<h2>SOUTH - The Sprawling Fields of Bone</h2> You swing the tiller landward, and your ship heels to your turn. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9JS]]<h2>YOU PRONOUNCE JUSTICE OVER SIGYN</h2> You speak to the assembled Maor and Aesgir: "The weight of this decision rests heavy on me. It is no small thing to hold the fate of a god in ones' hands. Blighted is the heart that chooses with open eyes the destruction of all things. An understandable madness perhaps, but fearsome in the annihilation it sought. Mercy's reach should be long, but we must temper it with wisdom. Consider that the risk of our judgement is the destruction of the World Tree itself. Should the door to apocalypse be opened because our hearts were bent by unfettered compassion? It cannot be. Though I desire greatly that mercy should rule the day, I will not risk the hearth and home of every creature, living or dead. Let the judgement of the Nine Worlds be just and wise. Let Sigyn be bound below the earth with Loki, that no such fate ever again befall the World Tree. This is my will, and the will of the Aesgir whose blessing I carry." ROLL A D20 TO PERSUADE YOUR FELLOW WARRIORS THAT YOUR RULING IS JUST! THIS IS THE LAST ROLL OF THE STORY!! (set: $JUSTICE to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $JUSTICE,"") [[Submit Total|JUSTICE Input]](set: _inputNum to (num: $JUSTICE)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die8") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 16)[ (go-to: "JUSTICE2") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 16)[ (go-to: "MERCY2") ] [[JUSTICE2]] [[MERCY2]] [[Rocks Fall And You Die8]]<h2>THE VOTES ARE CAST: JUSTICE PREVAILS!</h2> The seven assembled warriors of Midgard cast their votes, and when counted, the choice is for Justice - that Sigyn be bound below the earth! As votes are cast, Sigyn cries out, "It cannot be! You would condemn us again? You wretched worm of a man! Bind me well, for should I find means of loosing myself again, there will be no cooling my rage or thwarting my will! Consider this my oath! Frigga steps forth again and speaks. "I too will hold myself bound to this judgement, but I will also hold myself bound to my oath of relief. Even still, I shall come and hold the bowl that catches the serpent's poison in your stead, and grieve with you for the sufferings you've borne. It is right and good that I should bear this with you, as All-Mother, and long have I avoided my duty of love here. In time I hope that in bearing this burden, I might kindle the spark of forgiveness and restoration." Odin stands and speaks, "I too will bind myself by oath. This tragedy was born of my wrath, that blinded my eyes to the cost in suffering. If I am to be just and good in my rule of the Nine Realms, I must never forget in the cost of justice. To that end, I surrender my left eye. It shall be kept in the prison below the earth, where Sigyn and Frigga will often dwell. Ever and always they will be in my sight. So shall I bear witness to the flourishing of the Nine Realms with one eye, and bear witness to the grief born of love with the other, and be twice cautious in condemnation. " And Odin raises his hand to his left eye, and removes it, glowing brilliantly. He affixes it in a high place in the rock, watching in that dark place. And so it is even to this day... (link: "Continue...")[ Odin speaks again: "We consider the will of the Nine Worlds to be meted out. Let it be as this assembly has spoken." In a flash, you are gone again from the prison beneath Jotunheim, and instead you find yourself in Asgard's pearly courts. The golden boughs of Ygdrassil, now restored, wave and rustle with song. Odin appears, then Frigga, then the Aesgir of all the Nine Worlds and beyond. You stand at their center. I will swear on the honor of my house that the knowledge of it will not pass my lips." Thrym shifts uncomfortably: "That meeting was not the last I saw of her. She came again. Said she wanted to walk my world, to feel the raw earth without having to tend to that fool Loki. She asked me to let her wander the world alone. I let her. I thought I had a chance to take her into my house. She's a pretty one, and as sauce for the pig, it would stick it to Odin having one of his family as my wife. Never saw her after that. Its joints crackle with a horrifying sound as it moves, its eyes white and empty of all emotion save a cold, nihilistic madness! A Kaldsál! [[CONTINUE->KaldsalDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It leers at you menacingly, and as its fist descends, your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, ""Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[Continue|KaldsalDMG]]<h2>VICTORY!</h2> By merest accident, your blade has sunk deep into your onrushing foe as it grapples with you, impaling it! The cursed creature falls to its knees, bellowing its rage with its last feral breath, fading to a gurgle before it falls and lies still. You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over. You've won! (link: "Continue")[ But no sooner has the water settled from the battle, than nine great giants of Jotunheim come over the bluffs on all sides. "Who are you, and why do you trouble this realm. Speak quickly, for you have slain one of our brethren, and we would as soon break you as hear you." You stand and call out, "I come by the will of Odin and His Beloved, with a purpose greater than any one man or giant. You would do well to aid me or leave me be!" The gathered giants give a rough chuckle and advance on you. "The names of Odin and Frigga carry no weight here, manling..." [[[[CONTINUE->JOT1]]]] ]<h2>LET GO OF THE TREE AND FALL</h2> Against all logic, you breathe deep and let go of the tree. And you fall - gathering speed until you are blinded by the wind rushing past your face. And then you land, but not with the hard breaking of bones. Instead, you alight on a deep softness. You open your eyes, and you are standing on the golden leaves of the canopy of Ygdrassil! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 22->DAY 22C]]Your observations are cut short though, as the greatest of the herd, whose neck towers above the others, dips its head down and regards you with fierce wide-set eyes. You freeze, but it is no help. The creature bellows a warning and the herd skitters in all directions. All save the herd's leader, who bears down on you with frightening speed, swinging its great neck downwards to pommel you to the ground! You raise (print:$weapon) and shield to defend yourself... [[CONTINUE->LightDeerDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It crushes you in a deadly clawed embrace. Your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[Continue|LightDeerDMG]]<h2>VICTORY!</h2> By merest accident, your blade once again sinks deep into your onrushing foe, impaling it! The cursed beast curls in on itself and screeches in fear and pain at you, which turns to a whimper as it bleeds a silvery blood. You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over and you've won, but the victory is bitter. This creature fought you only to defend the herd. The teribble weight of harming an innocent by no fault of your own weighs on you. And no sooner has your heart stopped beating, than the very air is rent by a great sourceless voice, that echoes through you with measured inevitability. "WHY DO YOU ATTACK THE CREATURES OF MY REALM?" (link: "Continue")[ The light of the orchard plain is suddenly illuminated by an overwhelming living lumienscence: a shimmering, radiant presence of golden air that rises and coils into a singular, colossal form. The light resolves into features, first vague, then clear and magestic and mighty. Robes of living sunlight flow and swirl up a strong, graceful form, revealing skin that shines like polished bronze and eyes that burn with the blue of a midday sky. The great form of Freyr, Lord of Álfheim, leans towards you. His voice moves through the air, resonant like the great peal of a thousand titanic bells. "SPEAK YOUR PIECE, MAOR." [[CONTINUE->ALF1]] ]After many hours your weary hand can barely hold the tiller, and only your will keeps your eyes from closing. As the world fades behind your heavy eyelids, you hear in the distance a mighty and unearthly shriek! Instantly you are awake! You search the sky, and in the perpetual low dark clouds, you see a moving shadow, bearing down on you quickly! In the space of a breath the shadows coalesce into the shape of a sinuous angular body, and great leathery wings. A Magma Drake dives from the heights towards your ship, screeching its hunger! You heel your ship, and set as much sail as you can, then heft a great spear, shouting your defiance! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! If Ragnarok should come before its appointed time, you will surely be lost and consumed with her, and with all the Nine Worlds. If she lives and Ygrassil grows again, the destruction of Asgard appointed to you will once again be a certainty. Choose wisely - it matters not to me." "Mighty Surtr, Lord of Muspelheim, destined to burn the old world and forge the new. I have not come to beg for mercy or to ask for pity. I have come to recognize the truth of your power, a truth the gods refuse to see. Frigga All-Mother and her fool of a husband think I come in their name. They are deceived. The World Tree dies, and my concern is only that Midgard should survive it and be reborn. I offer you a chance to join the invisible hand that has brought forth Ragnarok before it's time. I will discover its source, and forge an alliance. Join me. Let us find the cause of this blight and turn it to our purposes: The burning of the world tree in a final, glorious blaze, so that from its magnificent ashes, a new, purer world can be born—one worthy of the Jotun of Muspelheim and the Maor of Midgard. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14MBS]]<h2>GOAD SURT WITH CONTEMPT</h2> You stare down the King of the Fire Realm, then begin to laugh. "I need neither your patience nor your permission, blind little god-let. I fear no ending you might inflict on me. You are a small God of a small world, so wrapped in his own thoughts that he will be an unending source of contempt to all generations, and then forgotten and extinguished by the weave of time. No, I fear only that I should not take my place amongst the warriors of Asgard, and that The World Tree should die of the blight you well know afflicts it. Lend me your aid, or begone and leave me to my work, but don't waste my time when the honor of my house is needed by your betters for higher tasks." His eyes grow flat, and the colors of Muspelheim that swirl on him intensify to brilliance. "No ant of Midgard should dare speak to me so. Why would I care for the will of Odin, or trust such a fragile and flawed vessel for his purposes. This is trickery, and ill-conceived trickery at that. Flee, vermin. Go back to your hovel. I will grant you the mercy of an hour before I lift my voice and turn all of Muspelheim against you. Flee and call upon the Old Fool and his witless wife to save your skin if they can. But I doubt they will." You turn, and limp desperately out of Surt's throneroom, not knowing where to go. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14MS]](set: _inputNum to (num: $MDirNumber)) Process Input (if: _inputNum is 1)[ (set: $Mdir to "MNorth") (go-to: "MNorth") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 2)[ (set: $Mdir to "MWest") (go-to: "MWest") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 3)[ (set: $Mdir to "MSouth") (go-to: "MSouth") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 4)[ (set: $Mdir to "MEast") (go-to: "MEast") ] (else:)[ (set: $Mdir to "Error") (go-to: "Potato is not a direction...4") ] [[MNorth]] [[MWest]] [[MSouth]] [[MEast]] [[Potato is not a direction...4]]You dive for the ship's hold, finding shelter there just before the rain overwhelms the ship in sheets of slick blackness. You find your spare sail, and wrap yourself in it. It keeps the greasy rain of Muspelheim from soaking you, and you are able to stand at the tiller and navigate the fiery seas. By and by the heavy, ashen air infiltrates your lungs, and your breath becomes ragged and dry. Imperceptibly at first, but then rapidly, your sight changes. The waves of the great sea become more than just as an endless expanse of flame. They are suffused with the currents of the life-blood of this world. The trails through the air of sparks and smoldering ash are traced by white light in a beautiful dance. The mighty life-blood of Muspelheim, hidden from your eyes before, is now revealed in all its glory: strange and beautiful and terrible. THE EITR OF MUSPELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. [[DAY 10->DAY 10ME]]<h2>YOU EXTEND MERCY TO SIGYN</h2> You speak to the assembled: "It is a twisted heart that chooses the destruction of all things, but it is a madness that can be understood. For whom amongst us is not bound to hearth and home by the cords of love. Who amongst us would not tear the heart from themselves if it would save the life of those we call kin. Whom of us could watch our beloved suffer pain and stave off the madness of grief. How much more then for Sigyn, whose vigil, born of loyalty, was eternal, and to whom no hope was given. We cannot condemn such a grief, nor entomb it once more beneath the mountains of Jotunheim. Let the judgement of the Nine Worlds be tempered by mercy. Our will is for clemency for this, and the right, when Frigga sits in her stead, that Sigyn should wander the worlds, and find them sweet again. This is my will, and the will of those in whose voice I speak." (set: $MERCY to "0") ROLL A PERSUASION CHECK TO SWAY THE THOUGHTS OF YOUR FELLOW WARRIORS - THIS IS THE LAST ROLL OF THE STORY!! (input-box: bind $MERCY,"") [[Submit Total|MERCY Input]](set: _inputNum to (num: $JUSTICE)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die8") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 16)[ (go-to: "MERCY2") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 16)[ (go-to: "JUSTICE2") ]<h2>THE VOTES ARE CAST: MERCY PREVAILS!</h2> The Seven assembled cast their votes, and when counted, Sigyn is to be shown mercy, in accordance with Frigga's oath! Sigyn speaks, "For this mercy I count myself indebted to Sons and Daughters of Midgard, for though they endured pain and fear at my hand, they found in themselves a deeper mercy. Truly they are great of heart, and their deeds here should be made known across the Nine Worlds." Frigga steps forth again and speaks. "I will still hold myself bound to my oath of relief. I shall come and hold the bowl that catches the serpent's poison in your stead, and grieve with you for the sufferings you've borne. It is right and good that I should bear this with you, as All-Mother, and long have I avoided my duty of love here. In time I hope that in bearing this burden, I might kindle the spark of forgiveness and restoration." Odin stands and speaks, "I too will bind myself by oath. This tragedy was born of my wrath, that blinded my eyes to the cost in suffering. If I am to be just and good in my rule of the Nine Realms, I must never forget in the cost of justice. To that end, I surrender my left eye. It shall be kept in the prison below the earth, where Sigyn and Frigga will often dwell. Ever and always they will be before my eye. So shall I bear witness to the flourishing of the Nine Realms with one eye, and bear witness to the grief born of love with the other, and be twice cautious in condemnation. " And Odin raises his hand to his left eye, and removes it, glowing brilliantly. He affixes it in a high place in the rock, watching in that dark place. And so it is even to this day... (link: "Continue...")[ Odin speaks again: "We consider the will of the Nine Worlds to be meted out. Let it be as this assembly has spoken." In a flash, you are gone again from the prison beneath Jotunheim, and instead you find yourself in Asgard's pearly courts. The golden boughs of Ygdrassil, now restored, wave and rustle with song. Odin appears, then Frigga, then the Vanir of all the Nine Worlds and beyond. You stand at their center. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 24->DAY 24]] ]You shade your eyes, but otherwise let the oil of this rain cover you. Its unctuous heaviness runs down your skin and into your clothes, soaking you through. You taste its metallic brimstone on your tongue. Gradually, the slick seems to be drawn into your flesh and bones, turning your skin a blackened grey, flaked with ash. It burns, but not with the pain of fire. Rather it is like the burn if a strong mead in your belly. You open your eyes and are astonished to see the waves of the great sea not just as an endless expanse of flame, but suffused with the currents of the life-blood of this world. The trails through the air of sparks and smoldering ash are traced by white light in a beautiful dance. The mighty life-blood of Muspelheim, hidden from your eyes before, is now revealed in all its glory: strange and beautiful and terrible. THE EITR OF MUSPELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES.
