Her coming is blessing indeed. With her as your companion, the wrath of Surtr cannot touch you. ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16MT]]<h2>INTIMIDATE SURT</h2> You stare back boldly at the Lord of the Fire Realm. "Leave me be, Fool of a God. I have no fear left for you. It is you who should fear: Surely you have felt the tremblings of the World Tree. Ragnarok comes early, and by a hand other than your own. You heard the words of the All-Mother, who watches the weave of time. Someone moves to take your appointed glory from you, and should that happen the ascendance of you and your kind is overcast by the shadow of doubt. Tell me, God of Fire, would you let another extinguish you from history? I an my kind are tasked with the saving of Ygdrassil. Kill me, and be forgotten in the void, or lend me your aid. But don't presume to waste my time. ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - HIGH DC, Surtr is arrogant enough to think he and Muspelheim can outlast all things. (set: $MCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $MCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $MCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2M") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 15)[ (go-to: "MCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 15)[ (go-to: "MCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>MANIPULATE SURT BY FLATTERY</h2> You remain on one knee and recover your breath for a moment, before looking up: Mighty, Surt, I have come to return to you your appointed task. Ragnarok ought to be yours and yours alone, by the arc of fate itself. The All-Mother and All-Father know this, and dare not take from you what is yours by right. I am here as your agent as much as theirs, to seek out the cause of this blight, so that the burning and rebirth of the world are by the might of fire, not the whimper of poisoned veins. Come, God of Fire, lend me your wisdom that I might avert this misshapen end. Let Ragnarok come by the hand and the will of the great God of Flame and his mighty sword, and by no other. ROLL FOR PERSUASION - LOW DC Surtr believes in his right to destroy Asgard, and that it makes him greater than the Aesir (set: $MCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $MCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $MCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2M") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 4)[ (go-to: "MCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 4)[ (go-to: "MCharmFAIL") ] ]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 18</h1> Many days later, with (print:$animal) as your guide once again, you find your way back to your ship, seemingly without Surt's knowledge of your passage. Remarkably it is intact, though blackened like coal by the fiery waters. The deck under your feet, and the smooth handle of the tiller feel like the greeting of an old friend. YOU ARE BACK ON YOUR SHIP, AND IT IS INTACT! ADD A REROLL OF ANY DIE TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE->DAY18M2]]<h2>APPEAL TO SURT'S HONOR</h2> You sink to one knee in respect, before looking up and addressing Surt. "Lord Surt, the Fated, Flame of Ragnarök, The gods' time is ending, a truth we both know. But a rotting world is a fate unworthy of your purpose. Your destiny is not to consume a sickened, dying husk. Your fire is a cleansing flame, meant to burn away a world at its peak. Your prophecy foretells the final, glorious act—the fiery end that forges a new beginning. If Yggdrasil falls before your blade can strike it, that beginning will never come. Do not let the gods' neglect steal your purpose. Honor the prophecy. Aid me in saving Yggdrasil so that when the time comes, it will be a world worthy of your fire. Only then can you fulfill your true destiny. ROLL FOR PERSUASION - LOW DC, Surt considers his destiny very important, and to destroy a great world is better to his mind than to destroy a weak world. (set: $MCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $MCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $MCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 7)[ (go-to: "MCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 7)[ (go-to: "MCharmFAIL") ] ]You find a rocky outcropping behind which is a small hollow. You huddle beneath it, just as the storm hits. You watch it swirl past with a mighty animal howl, the lines of sand and ash making a hypnotic dance. PRUDENCE IS THE BETTER PART OF VALOR: ADD THE DICE FROM TODAY (A D12) TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL, TO USE IN AID OF A FUTURE TASK OF YOUR CHOOSING! As you breathe in the turbulent air of the storm from your shelter, the dance of the wind ceases to sound like a predator's howl, and the bite of sand becomes the gentle touch of a warm breeze. You open your eyes and are astonished to see the very might of the storm moves past and through you, as if you are joined to it and a part of it. The trails through the air of sand, spark and smoldering ash are traced by white light in a beautiful dance. The mighty life-blood of Muspelheim, hidden from your eyes before, is now revealed in all its glory: strange and beautiful and terrible. THE EITR OF MUSPELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES By quick thinking, you are saved from the worst of the storm. By and by it blows itself out, and you are able to emerge into the light of the Muspelheim skies again. [[DAY 10->DAY 10MN]]You wrap a rag across your mouth and nose , and shade your eyes with a hand, but otherwise let the great storm of ash descend on you.The air, a moment ago clear and vast, turns to a suffocating curtain of ash and grit. The world narrows to a few feet around you, your vision swallowed by the storm. Sand whips at your exposed skin like a thousand tiny needles, and you instinctively turn your back, hunching your shoulders and burying your face in your arm. The sound of the storm is a low, relentless roar, Breathing becomes a conscious, difficult act, and each step is a battle against the unseen force of the wind, pushing and pulling you off course. The brimstone flavor of the ash invades your mouth and nose, and you are certain death is coming... But as you breathe in this mighty storm, the whip of the wind ceases to drive you back, and the bite of sand becomes the gentle touch of a warm breeze. You open your eyes and are astonished to see the very might of the storm move through you, as if you are joined to it and a part of it. The trails through the air of sand, spark and smoldering ash are traced by white light in a beautiful dance. The mighty life-blood of Muspelheim, hidden from your eyes before, is now revealed in all its glory: strange and beautiful and terrible. THE EITR OF MUSPELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES, BUT THE STORM HAS TAKEN A TOLL! YOU NEITHER GAIN NOR LOSE INSPIRATION DICE TODAY. [[DAY 10->DAY 10MN]]<h2>NORTH - The Obsidian Mountains</h2> You swing the tiller landward, and your ship heels to your turn in the fiery waves. Soon you feel the harsh grind of rock under the keel. The great obsidian mountain looms heavily over you. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9MN]]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 18</h1> Many days later, following in the footfalls of your companion, you return to Surt's Throneroom. He rises and regards you. "What have you found?" You throw the great fang on the table, and he lifts it to his eye. The Eitr of Muspelheim twists suddenly, as realization strikes him. "This is a fang of Jormungandr - the World Serpent. This must be by the hand of Sigyn. She would destroy me and the world of flame! What madness has driven her to this? "It shall not be - she will not rob me of my glory. Though it pains me to say, you must go to Asgard. Find the All-Father - he may be able to draw out the shape of Sigyn's plan, and how it might be unmade. Go, warrior! There is no time to lose!" And with a gesture he sends you whirling and twisting in the winds to land on the deck of your ship once more. YOU ARE BACK ON YOUR SHIP, AND IT IS INTACT! ADD A REROLL OF ANY DIE TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE->DAY18M2]]You slam your weapon into the nearby rock and shout to scare the creature off. Immediately, all disappear into their hollows. There is a moment's stillness, where only the river moves, before you too being your journey again. But not sooner has your back turned than you hear a mass skittering behind you. You turn and see the creatures swarming along the ground, teeth bared, skittering claws eating the distance between you! You turn and try to run, but are soon overtaken. Hundreds of them claw their way up your legs, or jump and grab your arms, torso, and face! You feel the sting of many fangs piercing your skin as you stumble onward, shaking the maddened creatures from you as best you can. The pain from the creatures bites are intense, and the pain threatens to overwhelm you! You fall forward, and in doing so seem to cross some invisible threshold, for the swarm suddenly retreats and skitters away in an instant. As the fear and panic subsidem, you look you see the bloodied indent of fangs all over your body. They burn like points of white fire, and spread rapidly throughout your body. You feel the course of the fire through your veins and watch your arm blacken and your skin flake like white ash along its length. You fall to your knees, arched in an all-consuming pain! But you don't die. Instead the pain subsides slowly, replaced by an inner fire, like that of a strong mead in your belly. You open your eyes and are astonished to see the coursing of fire through veins of rock and through the cracks in the obsidian obelisks. The trails through the air of sparks and smoldering ash. The mighty life-blood of Muspelheim, hidden from your eyes before, is now revealed in all its glory: strange and beautiful and terrible. THE EITR OF MUSPELHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. BUT AT A COST! YOU NEITHER GAIN NOR LOSE INSPIRATION DICE TODAY. [[DAY 10->DAY 10MS]]You kneel and offer the creature a conciliatory hand. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9MS]]Suddenly and everywhere the voice of Frigga All-Mother rings, as it did in your head a scant few days ago. "Stay your anger, Surtr. I am the Mother of Fate, and this one is here by my hand. You have surely felt the tremblings of the World Tree. I have sensed in the threads of time that some treachery seeks to rob both of us of our appointed times. Listen to this warrior. They will speak in my stead, for my power wanes, and my voice fails at this reach." And her presence is gone. Surtr turns his haughty gaze upon you, "So be it." In a haze, the dark horizon blurs, and you find yourself in a great throne room of searing fire, where the Eitr runs through your vision like heat on the air. The Light Elves took Alfheim for their own, and filled it with beauty and peace. The Dvergr took Suartalfheim, and made great halls under the earth of silver and gold and precious stones. For the Jotun, the giants, three realms were made. Muspelheim - land of fire, Niflheim - of ice, and Jotunheim of stone And Helheim, land of the forgotten dead, was bequeathed to Hel to bear her name and be her domain - both gift and curse. [[CONTINUE->MagmaDrakeDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> The great drake tears at the ship, rending the deck in half with its powerful claws as it clambers towards you. You are pitched headlong into the sea of fire. Your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the desperation of burning and drowning you should feel, clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" You've helmed your ship into jagged, unseen rocks on a hidden shore! You are flung forward, and your head slams against the deck! The illusions that seduced your eyes and ears grow thin, and fade to sighs, then to moans, then grow and crescendo to a high ragged stuttering keen. The fog grows thick, unnaturally thick above you. It draws to a faceless whorling form that towers above you on the deck of your ship. You feel cold and alone. The air draws the very life from you. You know this creature from stories - A Sjónhverfa! (input-box: bind $MirageNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|Mirage Input]] // The Sjónhverfa is not a physical creature but a living illusion that haunts fog-bound waters. It can project images of safe harbors, friendly ships, or even beloved long-lost family members onto the mists to lure weary sailors to their doom. When its prey has been drawn onto the rocks, the illusion disperses, and the sailors are left at the mercy of the brutal, icy waves. This creature doesn't appear in Norse Mythology, but is adapted to this story from some ideas eslewhere.//<h2>MISS!</h2> Your wild, half-hearted strike at the creature whistles through the mist-laden air, finding nothing! The Sjónhverfa swirls around your arm, numbing it and drawing the joy out of your very soul. You nearly drop your (print:$weapon)! (set: $MirageDmg1 to "0") ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! [[CONTINUE->Mirage2]]<h2>MISS!</h2> Your weapon finds only the mist, and the keening of the creature becomes a clicking guttural chuckle at your ineffectual swing! The four forms coalesce into one, which rushes at you, surrounding you in mist that saps your strength. Your blood runs cold in your veins! (set: $MirageDmg2 to "0") ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! [[CONTINUE->Mirage3]]<h2>MISS!</h2> You throw yourself to the side, but the mist swirls to encompass you. Your (print:$weapon) goes slack in your hand, and you feel the life draining from you! The creature crows a strange cry of victory! You fall to your knees, crying out in desperation, "HELP, ALL-MOTHER!" ENTER A ZERO FOR TODAY'S DAMAGE ROLL ON YOUR //JOURNAL OF BLIGHTED HEARTS// CARD, IF YOU HAVE ONE! (set: $MirageDmg3 to "0") THEN TOTAL YOUR DAMAGE FOR THE LAST 3 DAYS, AND PRESS CONTINUE! [[CONTINUE->MirageDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> The Sjónhverfa fully embraces you into its swirling form. All light and hope is drawn from you. You think with despair of home and hearth. Your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the overwhelming despair that you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, "Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" [[[[CONTINUE->HEL1]]]] ]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> You shake your head to clear the sleep from your mind. Something is not right. Home is worlds away, and you are on a strange sea. There is some devilry afoot! Even as your heart aches for home, you turn your ship away from the lantern's lights. The illusions that seduced your eyes and ears grow thin, and fade to sighs, then to moans, then grows and crescendoes to a high ragged stuttering keen. The fog grows thick, unnaturally thick. It draws to a faceless whorling form that crouches on the deck of your ship. A Sjónhverfa! You draw your (print:$weapon) and rush towards your mysterious foe! As you do, the (print:$amulet) hung around your neck glows and suffuses your weapon with an aura of light! ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! [[Continue|MirageDMG]]<h2>VICTORY!</h2> With the last of your strength you bring you (print:$weapon) around and drive it through the ethereal skull of the specter! You can see that it is a death-blow to the swirling form! The aura of light that clung to your armaments extends out and infuses the mist of the Sjónhverfa's form. The keening moan it emits stutters and dissipates, even as the light burns its form away! You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over. You've won! But no sooner has your heart stopped beating, than the very air is rent by a great sourceless voice, that echoes through you with measured inevitability. "WHY DO YOU ATTACK THE GUARDIANS OF MY SEAS?" (link: "Continue")[ The light of day is suddenly extinguished. Dark descends like a curtain, blurring colors downwards from the crown of the sky. Time around you slows altogether. The dark is alive. A moving, nebulous mass of shadow, rises and twists into a singular, colossal form. The shadow resolves into features, first vague, then clear and beautiful and terrible. A dress of living blackness swirls and blurs up a graceful form, to deep dark skin, and burning eyes. The great form of Nott, Goddess of the Night, leans towards you. Her voice moves through you as easily as a cold wind. "SPEAK YOUR PIECE, MAOR. SPEAK OR DIE." [[CONTINUE->NIF1]] ]The cool, watchful presence of the God Máni stands before you, his form shimmering with the soft, reflective light of the moon. Across his shoulder rests the great Silver Crescent. "I know of your quest, Maor," he says, his voice a quiet, measured echo, "and it will test you mightily. Go with the moon's blessing. It will guide your hand through the dark and be a light to you when all others fail." And he places around your neck the simple, polished moonstone amulet that is his symbol. It gathers the surrounding light and rests cool and calming against your chest, like a promise of return. Then he steps aside and gestures to your waiting ship. "It is time - the All-Father will soon open the way to the Bifrost. Make ready, and watch for horizon to split. Fair winds, Warrior!" Sigyn must have some secret purpose apart from his knowledge... [[GO TO DAY 15->DAY 15MS]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> Surt is trying to deceive you. His story has the air of lies built upon lies. You let silence hang in the throne room a moment, and then speak. "You speak but half of the truth, God of Fire. I can hear the weight of your falsehoods in your every word. I would be a fool to trust one who so easily betrays his allies, unless I knew all and held some power. You need me to uncover the truth of Sigyn's schemes. Tell me what you have withheld. Surt's eyes flair, but you have his measure - he needs your aid. After a time, he reclines and gestures a thin indifference. "Vey well, Maor. The tremblings of the World Tree have extended farther into my realm than my reckoning allowed for. I suspect that Sigyn's vengeance is blighted by madness that would destroy even Muspelheim itself. I need assurances that her means of destroying the Tree do not extend destruction further than even fate should allow. If she is mad beyond all reckoning, and seeks to destroy even my realm, she must be stopped." ADD THE D20 FROM TODAY TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! The fiery zephyr bears down on you, and you fall to the ground, curling your knees to your face. You are lost to the storm! All is chaos... Then, inexplicably, all is calm. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 15->DAY 15MD]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> You throw your cloak over your head to ward off the flying debris, and race towards a small overhang at the base of a tall scree. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 15->DAY 15MD]]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Surt speaks the truth. Sigyn must have some secret purpose apart from his knowledge... [[GO TO DAY 15->DAY 15MS]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> You can tell by intuition Surt is trying to deceive you. You let silence hang in the throne room a moment, and then speak. "You lie, God of Fire. I can hear the weight of your falsehoods in your every word. But I will make you a deal. Already you have told me you were outwitted by one whose might you utterly dwarf. I hold the key to make right the wrongs you have allowed by your foolishness. I will make you a deal. Tell me the whole truth, and I will swear to never let the story you have told cross my lips, even to death and beyond." Surt's eyes flair, but you have his measure - he cannot bear to be seen more lowly than the Aesgir. After a time, he reclines and gestures a thin indifference. "Vey well, Maor. I was not overwrought by Sigyn's deceit. I joined her in her schemes, believing her purposes and mine were aligned. I told her the way to Ginnungagap, and bid her do what she willed to the root of Ygdrassil. If Ragnarok could be made to come sooner, and it required nothing of me, I saw no reason to stay her hand. Muspelheim was before and will be after, and I believed nothing could shake its foundations. But it appears she is mad beyond all reckoning, and seeks to destroy even my realm. She must be stopped." ADD THE D20 FROM TODAY TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 15->DAY 15MS]]<h2>CONVINCE YOUR ANIMAL COMPANION TO HELP!</h2> You look to (print:$animal), who regards you motionlessly. You raise your hand, and address her: "I need your aid, faithful avatar of Niflheim. Have you the power to still the waters of Hvergelmir? I must find the source of this poison!" (input-box: bind $D16NANumber1,"") [[Submit Number|D16NA Input]]<h2>APPEAL TO A HIGHER AUTHORITY</h2> You consider with care, then speak: "Great Nott, Rider of the Night, you are a part of the great order of things, just as I am a son of Midgard, and just as the All-Father is the keeper of all the realms. Odin's ravens, Huginn and Muninn, have circled the boughs of Yggdrasil. They have seen the blight that spreads, and their thoughts are grim. The wisdom of the All-Father is without equal, and he has decreed that every being, from the gods in Asgard to the great giants of the night, has a role to play in this coming battle. Your journey is not just your own, Nott. It is a part of the order Odin has given to the cosmos. He has set the stars in their courses and commanded the sun to follow its path. Your ride is a part of that very command. To see the World Tree fall is to see Odin's own design crumble into chaos. Would you defy the will of the All-Father? Do you believe you are so distant in your dark chariot that his power does not touch you? The world you rule, the night that is at your command —it all exists because of the great Tree that he protects. You will not escape the end that is coming. Answer me, Nott. Will you prove yourself worthy of the All-Father's favor and aid us in this struggle, or will you become a victim of the chaos that comes from defying his will? ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - HIGH DC, Nott considers herself Odin's equal, and is indifferent to his authority. (set: $NCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! I have not come to you as a beggar, but as a man who knows the value of a powerful ally. The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is sick with a rot that spreads from its deepest roots. The fate of all nine realms, including your own endless journey, hangs in the balance. When the tree falls, the sky you so proudly ride will collapse, and the darkness you command will be lost to chaos. This is not a battle you need to face alone. Lend us your strength, Nott. Aid us in this fight to save Yggdrasil. The All-Father, Odin himself, has foreseen this struggle. He does not offer his favor lightly, but he knows the value of a mighty ally in these dark times. He and the other Aesir would look upon your aid as a sign of great courage and wisdom. Help us save the cosmos, and you will not only secure the future of your night, but you will win the favor and gratitude of the gods themselves. An alliance with Asgard, a place of honor among the Aesir—that is the reward for your strength." ROLL FOR DECEPTION - MEDIUM DC. Nott Isn't much swayed by the offer of an alliance with the Aesgir, but she would see the wisdom of self-preservation here. (set: $NCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $NCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $NCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2N") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 8)[ (go-to: "NBribePASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 8)[ (go-to: "NCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>GOAD NOTT WITH CONTEMPT</h2> You let a slow sneer curl your lips as you speak: Do you even see the rot, Nightwalker? Or are your eyes as blind as your light is weak? You ride across the heavens each night, a tedious march for a fleeting shadow. You bring a darkness that is mere servant to the sun—a hollow, empty thing that always, always gives way to the dawn. You are not a force of the cosmos; you are a simple trick, a veil pulled over a sleeping world. And now, your simple world is ending. Yggdrasil, the mighty tree that holds up your pitiful sky, is blighted. When it falls, the realms will plunge into the void—not the soft, pretense of darkness you hold so loosely. This will be the true darkness, the one that knows no end and has no need for a weak goddess to bring it. When the abyss swallows all, your little ride will end. Your horse, Hrimfaxi, will have no sky to gallop in, and your weak shadow will be snuffed out without a whisper. You will not be a casualty of a great war. You will not be remembered at all. Your darkness will simply be consumed by a darkness that knows you not, and cares less. So tell me, Nott. Is your night anything more than a passing shadow? If it is, join your cause to Odins, or be consumed. It matters not to me." ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - HIGH DC, Nott is a proud Goddess, and will not appreciate the contempt. (set: $NCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $NCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $NCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2N") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 16)[ (go-to: "NCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 16)[ (go-to: "NCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>FAILURE!</h2> Nott is unswayed by your entreaties. Her expression grows flat, and the swirling mists of Niflheim around her intensify to an impossibly chilling gray. "You speak of a great sickness and a need for unity, but I hear only the foolish prattle of a creature that does not comprehend its own insignificance. "You ask me to lend my strength to save a Tree? You speak of a flaw in the very order the gods so foolishly made. Why would I care for a sickness that cannot touch me?" Your world, your Tree, your gods—they are but a brief, bright flicker in the dark. My night is primordial. It was here before the worlds were forged from fire and ice, and it will remain when they are all dust. Your blight is a disease of the branches, a sickness of the fleeting. I am the very root, the endless, unchanging shadow from which all things emerged. I have no quarrel with a sickness that cannot touch me. But with you, who have sown chaos with every step, and nearly killed those who guard my realm. I have emnity with you. "Flee, manling. Flee before the night and the frost. I will stay my hand against you for an hour, since you come under the banner of the All-Mother, but following that should you be found in Niflheim, the very darkness will consume you." You turn, your breath freezing in the air, and limp desperately away from Nott's silent, icy throne, not knowing where to go. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14ND]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> Nott regards you steadily for long moments, "So be it, mortal. Tell me what you know of the blight of the World Tree." You give Nott an account, of the failing of the World Tree, and of your journey thus far. When done she sits a long time, deep in thought. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14NS]](set: _inputNum to (num: $NDirNumber)) Process Input (if: _inputNum is 1)[ (set: $Ndir to "NNorth") (go-to: "NNorth") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 2)[ (set: $Ndir to "NWest") (go-to: "NWest") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 3)[ (set: $Ndir to "NSouth") (go-to: "NSouth") ] (else-if: _inputNum is 4)[ (set: $Ndir to "NEast") (go-to: "NEast") ] (else:)[ (set: $Ndir to "Error") (go-to: "Potato is not a direction...5") ] [[NNorth]] [[NWest]] [[NSouth]] [[NEast]] [[Potato is not a direction...5]]You attempt to guide your ship away from the great arch. It is magnificent, but you think it better to be wary of the glamour of a quiet world. But the Still Sea is deceptive. A subtle current has taken the ship captive, and there is no wind to fight it! You take up a long oar and try to fend the ship off using the sides of the iceberg as leverage. You are able to wedge the oar into a crevasse in the ice, and drive it through the ship's rail, slowing your progress. The wood of the oar groans and splinters, then explodes in your grasp, driving shards of wood into your face and hands! You ship is swept towards the arch. You climb to the sternmost point, hoping to stave off passing through the hazed magic that hangs under it. It only delays the inevitable. With fear and trembling you submit yourself to it. A surprising warmth blankets you, and the shimmer in the air becomes a slow patient weight in your flesh. Your very eyes awaken, and of a sudden you see the inevitability of time itself, stretched across the water, the sky, your hands, the very air; like a gentle blur. The patience of ice on stone. The resting waters. The settled anticipation of millenia before and after. THE EITR OF NIFLHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES, BUT YOUR INJURIES WILL SLOW YOUR PROGRESS AND DULL YOUR WITS! YOU NEITHER GAIN NOR LOSE AN INSPIRATION DIE TODAY. [[DAY 10->DAY 10NE]]You stay the course through the great arch. It envelops first the bowsprite, then the sail, then moves toward you. With fear and trembling you submit yourself to it. A surprising warmth blankets you, and the shimmer in the air becomes a slow patient weight in your flesh. Your very eyes awaken, and of a sudden you see the inevitability of time itself, stretched across the water, the sky, your hands, the very air; like a gentle blur. The patience of ice on stone. The resting waters. The settled anticipation of millenia before and after. THE EITR OF NIFLHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES! Her coming is blessing indeed. With her as your companion, the wrath of Nott cannot touch you. ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (input-box: bind $D16NFNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|D16NF Input]]<h2>INTIMIDATE NOTT</h2> You choose your words with care, "Great Nott, Rider of the Dark, I have come to you not with a plea for pity, but with a warning that will chill even you. The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is blighted. Its leaves wither, its bark cracks, and a deep rot spreads from its roots to its highest boughs. The sky you ride through each night is not some empty void, but held up by the strong limbs of the World Tree, held firm by its endless might. When the tree falls, the sky will fall with it. Where will you ride then, Nott? Where will your horse, Hrimfaxi, find a path to tread when the very path itself has crumbled into dust? Your darkness is a gentle thing, a cloak that brings rest and silence to the worlds. But the darkness that will come when Yggdrasil falls is not yours. It is the chaos that existed before the worlds were made. The primordial abyss that swallows all light, all sound, and all life. Do not think you are safe in your dark chariot. When the great trunk of the World Tree shatters, the cosmos will tear asunder. The worlds will plunge into the void. And you, and your night, will be swallowed with them. Lend us your aid, lest your beautiful darkness be snuffed out by the final, eternal night." ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - LOW DC. You speak the truth, insofar as you know it, and Nott will see the wisdom of your words. (set: $NCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $NCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $NCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2N") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 5)[ (go-to: "NCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 5)[ (go-to: "NCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>MANIPULATE NOTT BY FLATTERY</h2> You consider carefully, then speak: "O Nott, glorious Rider of the Dark, it is with the greatest respect that I come to your hall. The wisdom of men is but a fleeting spark, but your ancient knowledge is as vast as the blackness you command. I have seen the way you guide your horse, Hrimfaxi, through the heavens, an artist painting the world with your beautiful, encompassing shadow. You do not merely bring night; you bring rest, solace, and the silence in which great thoughts are born. Your passage is the very rhythm of the cosmos, a force as profound and necessary as the sun's fiery grace. But even a force as great as yours is bound to the order of things. The World Tree, Yggdrasil, upon which all the realms rest and all the stars are set in their courses, is blighted. A foul sickness spreads through its roots, threatening to unravel the very tapestry of existence. You, whose beauty and strength command the night itself, surely you see that the fate of your glorious domain is tied to the fate of the Tree. A queen cannot rule without a realm. If Yggdrasil falls, the sky you so elegantly ride will crumble, and your unending journey will be lost to chaos. Noble Nott, the realms require your strength and your wisdom now more than ever. Lend us your aid, and prove that your greatness is not merely in the darkness you bring, but in your power to save the cosmos from a darkness that would consume all." ROLL FOR PERSUASION -MEDIUM DC. Nott isn't much affected by flattery, but she will see that you speak the truth. (set: $NCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $NCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $NCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2N") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 10)[ (go-to: "NCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 10)[ (go-to: "NCharmFAIL") ] ]<h1>CALENDAR DAY 18</h1> Time is of the essence! [[CONTINUE->DAY18N3]]<h2>APPEAL TO NOTT'S HONOR</h2> You drop to one knee, then address Nott: "Nightmother, I come to you not as a stranger, but as a man who knows the bond of family. I bring a warning that should stir the deepest parts of your heart. The World Tree, Yggdrasil, sickens. Its roots rot, its leaves wither, and the very air around it grows thin. Do you not feel it, Nott? Do you not feel the trembling in the Great Tree? Your own daughter, Jörð, the earth underfoot, is a world held in place by that great Tree's power. When Yggdrasil falls, she will fall with it. She will be cast into the abyss, a broken shell swallowed by the void. What mother can stand by and watch her own flesh and blood expire? And what of your son, Dagr? His journey, his light, follows your own shadow across the heavens. Where will his chariot ride when the sky itself tears asunder? The endless cycle of day and night, the very rhythm of your family, will cease. He will be lost forever. Your duty is not merely to the night you bring, but to the kin you have borne. The fate of your children is bound to this tree. I ask you, Nott, will you not lend us your aid in service of your own blood? Or will you stand by and watch your family plunge into nothingness? I have sensed in the threads of day and night, that some treachery seeks to rob both of us of our appointed times. Listen to this warrior. They will speak in my stead, for my power wanes, and my voice fails at this reach." And her presence is gone. Nott turns her unreadable eyes upon you, "So be it." In a haze, the dark horizon blurs, and you find yourself in a great throne room of polished black ice, where the Eitr runs through your vision like the slow blur of time. She allowed the newly dead to cross over, and prevented the dead beyond the river from crossing back into the lands of the living.// (link: "Continue")[ Módgudr stalks back across the bridge to your prone form. She kicks you in the side, and says "Do you know where you are, Maor?" You shake your head. "This is the Bridge called Gjallarbrú. It separates the living of the Eight Realms above from the dead of Helheim. In your arrogance and ignorance you have nearly slain Garm, the hellhound that keeps the dead from mingling with the living. I should throw you into the chasm and be done with you." You attempt to speak, but she kicks you again in the ribs. You feel bones break. "Keep your words, manling. I will not kill you. Yet." "You are a mouthpiece of the Aesgir, and so must speak to my mistress, Nott. If the All-Mother sends an envoy to the Queen of the Night, I will stay my wrath. But know this, worm." And she leans close from her towering height, "My heart would be gladdened to feel you crushed beneath my hand, and I may yet have the pleasure!" (link: "Continue")[ She binds your hands and feet, and attaches to them a lead of heavy rope. After tending to the wounds of Garm, she drags you bodily away from the great chasm. For a long day she rakes you across the terrain as she travels. You are beaten and bruised to insensibility. On the second day, she relents, and removes the binding from your feet, allowing you the meagre mercy of running behind her, instead of dragging you. It is hellish. After a second long day, you come, bloodied and beaten, to the Throne room of Nott, Queen of the Night. It is made of darkened ice, polished to a mirror in every surface, and collecting and refracting the light to a darkened glow, as if the night that this place contains is alive in its very being. She would destroy me and my realm! What madness has driven her to this? "It shall not be - she will not rob me of my place in the sky. Though it pains me to say, you must go to Asgard. Find the All-Father - he may be able to draw out the shape of Sigyn's plan, and how it might be unmade. Go, warrior! There is no time to lose!" And with a gesture she sends you whirling and twisting in the winds to land on the deck of your ship once more. But that was not the last I saw of her - she came again, saying the waters taken on her first journey were not sufficient to the task, and more were required. "I gave her leave to return to the Hvergelmir. A mother should have rest from her sorrows. I count us bound by common suffering. Why should I refuse her?" Well since I can't throat-punch you from here, [[Try Again...I guess?->DAY 23]] ] (stop:) ]<h2>APPEAL TO A HIGHER AUTHORITY</h2> You bow your head to Mostognir and the assembled Dvergr, and then step forward and speak boldly: "I come in the name of the All-Father, whose hands shaped the Nine Norlds. He sees all, and all authority is his. My words are his words to you in a time of great darkness. You are commanded for your own sake, and for the sake of the Great Tree, to render to me what aid you can. Have you not felt the moving of the rocks beneath your feet? Do not the cornerstones of your great mountains shake and shudder like children in the night? Have you not seen the Eitr slow and still as it never has before your waking eyes? All of this finds its source in a terrible blight upon the World Tree, wrought not only on your realm, but on every one of the Nine, and spreading quickly. Its roots are blackening, even now, beneath your very throne. This unseen rot will not be stopped by armies, or by cunning craft. Only by the well-laid plans and strategies of all, working as one at Odin's behest. I am here on that errand. Heed the All-Father, or be remembered as the Dvergr King who defied the Will of Asgard in arrogance, and then watched his kingdom crumble to dust. What say you?" ROLL FOR PERSUASION - High DC. "Hail, First-born of the Dvergr. I come with a warning and with an opportunity. Surely you have felt the moving of the rocks beneath your feet, and the Eitr slow and still as it never has. All of this finds its source in a terrible blight upon the World Tree. A blight that can be traced to Odin's folly. The All-Father is arrogant and blind, and the tree's death is a testament to his waning power. This blight is not a threat to you and I, but an opportunity. An opportunity to prove that the Maor and the Dvergr are not just survivors, but masters of this coming new age. Odin has mistaken me for an ally. My will is to use his weakness to hasten his downfall, and raise up Midgard to where he once stood. If you would join me, I will gladly raise up Svartalfheim alongside Midgard." "What say you, King of the Dvergr? Would you join your will to mine?" ROLL FOR DECEPTION - LOW DC. Mostognir is delighted at the opportunity to undermine Odin's power and raise himself and his people up! (set: $SCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $SCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $SCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2S") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 3)[ (go-to: "SCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 3)[ (go-to: "SCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>GOAD MOSTOGNIR WITH CONTEMPT</h2> You stare boldly back at Mostognir, and then sneer at him and the assembled Dvergr: "For a King who sees much, Mostognir, your vision is as weak as a blinded mole's. You look out over your vast kingdom of iron and stone and gold and see a grand foundation. I see a fool standing on a pillar of cosmic rot. You think you sit on an eternal throne of bedrock that nothing can shake. I know you to sit in a land that is mere moments from crumbling dust and ash. Odin has not sent me to beg for help—he sent me to warn you that you are blind, and your blindness will be your true undoing. Have you not felt the moving of the rocks beneath your feet? Do not the cornerstones of your great mountains shake and shudder like children in the night? Have you not seen the Eitr slow and still as it never has before your waking eyes? And to all this you turn a blind eye. Who is now the fool, Maggot King? The blight of Ygdrassil will achieve what no army of men or giants or gods could: it will turn your unyielding iron to brittle dust and turn your mighty works to twisted wrecks of metal. And all because you were too proud to acknowledge a threat you couldn't solve with a hammer and a drink. You won't be remembered for your vaults of gold, King. You will be the legend of the Dvergr who saw all, and chose to be blind. If you would open your eyes, maggot king, and join your will to mine and Odins, we will still accept your aid. But if not, leave me to my work or kill me. But do not presume to waste my time." ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - HIGH DC. You've humiliated Mostognir in his own halls. This better be good... (input-box: bind $ScyllaNumber1,"") [[Submit Number|Scylla Input]] //The Scylla is actually borrowed from Homer's Odyssey. She is a six-headed monster that guards a narrow strait opposite a deadly whirlpool called Charbydis. According to the myth she has twelve feet, six long snaking necks, with grisly sharp teeth atop each. //<h2>FAILURE!</h2> A stony silence is the only response to your words for a long moment. Mostognir's eyes bore into you, gaging your appeal and its implications. Finally, he chuckles, a dry, grating sound like stone dragging on stone, and seizes his great horn cup. He raises it up and says to the assembled Dvergar, "Here is a Maor worthy of a laugh! If we were to bend our metal as easily as this one bends truth, our craft would shame even the weakest thrall! I have heard enough of your tale, manling. I know of the blight, and of the tremors, and of the slowing of the Eitr. You speak of the stone as if you know it, fool. As if we have not known and survived the tremors in the stone before. You would turn all these signs against us to our ruin. You speak of our pride? Our legacy?" He spits a mouthful of ale onto the floor. "Yggdrasil is a burden for the Aesgir, not for those who craft mighty works beneath its roots. I will not trade the security of this mountain for their fragile tree." I also know that if the tree falls, the gods will fall first, leaving us masters of the chaos. And should it be so, we will build from the ashes a world of stone and metal and fire that will put to shame the glory of Asgard. "Be gone from my sight." He rises and says, "Flee into whatever hole you can find to hide. For sport, I will hold back the might of the Dvergr to crush you until I have finished my drink, but not beyond." "Run, Manling. I grow thirsty" And he laughs a bellowing laugh and lifts his drinking horn to his lips. You flee. [[CONTINUE->DAY 14SD]]<h2>SUCCESS!</h2> A stony silence is the only response to your words for a long moment. Mostognir's eyes bore into you, gaging your honesty and its implications. Finally, he smirks and seizes his great horn cup. He raises it up and says to the assembled Dvergr, "Here is a Maor worthy of the courage and skill of the Dvergr! If we should learn to bend metal as this one bends words, our craft would surpass even the work of Andvari himself!" He salutes you and drinks deeply from his cup. "You have my ear, Maor." He says, "Tell us your tale, and I will consider it." You relay the details of your adventure from the beginning; of Odin's words to you, of Frigga's presence and that of the other Aesgir, of the Bifrost and of Svartalfheim as you have known it thus far. You also tell him of the change in your sight - that you see the movement of the Eitr in his world, and would have it restored to health. And when you have told all, he sits deep in thought. Finally, he rises and says, "Come with me, manling. We will speak in private." (link: "Continue")[ You continue threading your way through the crowded canals, though the air becomes thick and heavy with dry acrid dust. You cough and sputter, closing your eyes and leaning against the tiller. It is as if you are attempting to breathe underwater. Then in an instant, the air is not so foul to you. You open your eyes, and find that your very sight has changed as well! The stone walls are no longer inert. They are slow and careful workers, grinding and pushing to make gold out of dross. You see the Dark Elves that surround you, and through their feet and hands the slow life-blood of this realm ripples and pulses like a thick taut rope, thrumming with tension and life. It is the living patience of the realm of deep stone. It is brooding and beautiful. THE EITR OF SVARTALFHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES! [[DAY 10->DAY 10SE]] ]<h2>DROP YOUR WEAPON AND ASCEND</h2> You set down your shield, and go back the way you just came. In a mere few ascended steps you find the stairs end, widening into a chamber where the tree's grain weaves on the walls into a dazzling pattern of infinite complexity. Lines cross and weave in a maze of delightful dances, unforming to your eye, only to flower into a new pattern again. You go back for your shield, but it has disappeared! LOSE A DIE FROM YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! By and by your eye is drawn to where all patterns converge, arching overhead and downwards to a glowing, shining orb at the chamber's center, wreathed round with the pattern that paints the walls: the Seed of Ygdrassil! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 22->DAY22E]]<h2>DROP YOUR SHIELD AND CONTINUE TO DESCEND</h2> You set down your shield, and continue descending the steps. After a minute's descent, nothing has changed. You retrace your steps, but your shield is gone! LOSE A DIE FROM YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! [[TRY AGAIN->DAY 21E]]You regard the water running down your hand, and raise it to your lips with no small fear. But it's taste is sweet to your lips, and as you consume it, your eyes and ears are awakened. You turn your eyes to the solid stone of the bank, and they are not inert. They grind slowly and inevitably like great collossae, pushing and flexing to make gold out of dross. You see the waters that run in the canal and through them the slow life-blood of this realm ripples and pulses like a thick taut rope, thrumming with tension and life. It is the living patience of the realm of deep stone. It is brooding and beautiful. THE EITR OF SUARTALFHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES! YOU GAIN AN INSPIRATION DICE TO YOUR DICE POOL, TO USE IN AID OF A FUTURE TASK OF YOUR CHOOSING. [[DAY 10->DAY 10SE]]<h2>EAST - The Canals of Svartalfheim</h2> You nudge your ship's course further into the currents of the canal, and are carried forward into the press of laden transports as they move slowly downriver. The long slim craft around you are piloted by what can only be Dvergr. They are smaller in stature, but barrel-chested and straight-backed, and their clothes and adornments are generally of finer make. They glare at you with varying degrees of suspicion across the waters. The other inhabitants of the transports are tall well-muscled figures with bent backs, who keep their heads low, and avoid eye contact. They go about their business with the weight of weariness upon them. These must be the Dark Elves. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9SE]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> "This is Falki, my she-hawk. She will show you to Ymir's body, and aid you in undoing Sigyn's madness." Falki soars from the heights of the cold hall and lands on Freyr's shoulder, regarding you with knowing eyes. She is the might of the wind incarnate, and the Eitr flows around her as an adornment of royalty. ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16ST]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> A great hawk stares back at you with knowing eyes.She is the might of the wind incarnate, and the Eitr flows around her as an adornment of royalty. You stay frozen in place, scarcely daring to breathe, but the great hawk makes no hostile move. Instead she wheels down the dark street, then perches and looks back at you expectantly. You know this beast from the elders' stories: This is Falki, she-hawk protector of Svartalfheim. With her as your companion, Mostognir's wrath cannot touch you. This is blessing indeed! ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16ST]]<h2>THE HAWK</h2> A great hawk surrounded by a nimbus of glowing light swoops down from the shadowed heights above, scattering the assembled soldiers and standing over you, wings outdstretched. She screams a terrible, ear-piercing scream and the Dvergr flee in abject terror. In mere moments the streets are deserted, save for you and the hawk. You crawl slowly away from her, hands raised, but the great beast makes no hostile move. Instead, she stares back at you with knowing eyes. She is the might of the wind incarnate, and the Eitr flows around her as an adornment of royalty. Abruptly, she launches into the air, and swoops on silent wings down the dark street. She alights once more, then looks back at you expectantly. You know this beast from the elders' stories: This is Falki, she-hawk protector of Svartalfheim. With her as your companion, Mostognir's wrath cannot touch you. This is blessing indeed! ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Falki") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16ST]]<h2>STRIKE FEAR IN THE HEART OF MOSTOGNIR</h2> You bow your head to Mostognir, and then proclaim to him and the assembled Dvergr: "I have seen enough of this realm to call it great, First-Born of the Dvergr. Gold and precious gems flow like water from your mines, and your peoples' hands build mighty monuments and craft works of beauty and ingenuity. Were I you, I too would scoff from my throne of unmoving rock. But I tell you, I do not come to overthrow or undermine the work of Dvergr hands. Have you not felt the moving of the rocks beneath your feet? Do not the cornerstones of your great mountains shake and shudder like children in the night? Have you not seen the Eitr slow and still as it never has before your waking eyes? Call me a fool if you will, but believe your eyes when they echo the truths I speak. All of this finds its source in a terrible blight upon the World Tree, wrought not only on your realm, but on every one of the Nine, and spreading quickly. Its roots are blackening, even now, beneath your very throne. Odin has no desire to take from you your kingdom. He has sent me to root out the cause of this blight, and effect its cure if I can. And if not, the blight will not stop at timber and root. It will turn pure iron to rust. It's poison will makes granite crack and crumble without heat or hammer. You will not fall in glorious battle, or live forever in your great halls; your immortal mountains will disintegrate into dust while you watch. Join your will to mine and Odin's, Great King, and turn back the blight for your sake, and the sake of all creation! What say you?" ROLL FOR INTIMIDATION - MEDIUM DC. You speak the truth, insofar as you know it, and Mostognir will see the wisdom of your words. (set: $SCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $SCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $SCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2S") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 9)[ (go-to: "SCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 9)[ (go-to: "SCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>MANIPULATE MOSTOGNIR BY FLATTERY</h2> You bow your knee, then address Mostognir: "Hail king of the Dvergr. I bring greetings and an offer of friendship from Midgard and from the All-Father himself. Long has the might of Asgard been joined to the glory of Svartalfheim. Gungnir, the spear that flies from Odin's hand was first wrought by your forges. The chain that binds Fenrir in his prison comes from the ingenuity of the Dvergr. More than all others, the Aesgir and the Dvergr bear up the order of the universe on their great shoulders. Odin would have it no other way, and so he calls on you in his hour of need. There is a blight on Ygdrassil. A foul sickness spreads through its roots, threatening to unravel the very tapestry of existence. If the Great Tree should fail, all beautiful works of Dvergr hands will be undone and forgotten. You know this to be true, wise king. The pillars shake even here, and the Eitr of Svartalfheim is sluggish. Let your great wisdom govern your will. Join your cause to the All-Father and All-Mother. We would have your works remembered and their praises sung by every realm, to Ragnarok and beyond! ROLL FOR PERSUASION - LOW DC - Mostognir doesn't really trust Odin, but likes being called co-equal with him! (set: $SCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $SCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $SCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2S") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 6)[ (go-to: "SCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 6)[ (go-to: "SCharmFAIL") ] ]<h2>APPEAL TO MOSTOGNIR'S HONOR</h2> You consider carefully, then speak: "Hail King of Svartalfheim and Father of the Dvergr! I come to you with the shadow of fear on my heart. Not for myself, but for the family I have left behind. The All-Father and All-Mother called me because I know what it is to gladly bear on my shoulders the well being of family. This Odin knows and Frigga knows. This also you know, Great King. Your family is far greater in number and in bond than mine. Every Dvergr who calls this land home is your child, and their well-being is yours to bear on your great shoulders. You too have felt the World Tree, sicken. Its roots rot, its leaves wither, and a blight infects its veins. You have felt the tremors, no doubt, in your own realm. Do no the walls and pillars of your once-immovable home shake and groan in protest? The precious Eitr of Svartalfheim flows thick and sluggish, and I tell you mighty King, it is the blight! If the tree dies, your ceilings of stone will come down upon you and your children, and none will survive. So it will be for me, and my family. And so even unto the All-Father and All-Mother. The void will swallow everything, and there will be no rebirth. Come, Dvergr-Father. Join your cause to ours and save your kin. There can be no higher calling!" ROLL FOR PERSUASION - Medium DC. These claims on Mostognir are more tenuous - he has no direct family, only his subjects. (set: $SCharm to "0") ENTER YOUR TOTAL ROLL! (input-box: bind $SCharm,"") (link: "Submit Number")[ (set: _inputNum to (num: $SCharm)) (if: _inputNum is not a number)[ (go-to: "Rocks Fall And You Die2S") ] (else-if: _inputNum >= 11)[ (go-to: "SCharmPASS") ] (else-if: _inputNum < 11)[ (go-to: "SCharmFAIL") ] ]You raise the glass to your lips. The smell makes your eyes water, and the liquid moves like molasses. This is poison, and you are no fool. You mime tasting of it, and return your cup to the elf who passed it to you. He eyes you suspiciously, but says nothing. Your host, and the patrons of the tavern, are reluctant to speak, but by persistence and slow and careful conversation you are able to learn something of the mine you've entered: The Dvergr rule here, and the Dark Elves work. The mine is dangerous for many reasons, some of them alive and with a taste for blood. The mines are many leagues deep, and you would do well to find a guide. No, they will not be the guide - their work calls to them. By and by, they rise and turn back to their work. The conversation is very obviously over. You turn away as well, and continue your journey with the comforting knowledge that in this realm, as in Midgard, some things never change... (link: "Continue")[ You continue down the mine shafts, though the air becomes thick and heavy with dry acrid dust. You cough and sputter, leaning against a nearby wall. It is as if you are attempting to breathe underwater. Then in an instant, the air is not so foul to you. You open your eyes, and find that your very sight has changed as well! You turn your eyes to the stone walls, and they are not inert. They are slow and careful workers, grinding and pushing to make gold out of dross. You see the Dark Elves that surround you, and through their feet and hands the slow life-blood of this realm ripples and pulses like a thick taut rope, thrumming with tension and life. It is the living patience of the realm of deep stone. It is brooding and beautiful. THE EITR OF SVARTALFHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES! [[DAY 10->DAY 10SN]] ]You raise the glass to your lips. The smell makes your eyes water, and the liquid moves like molasses. Its taste is like ash and fire. Out of courtesy to your host, you drink it down and replace the cup on the counter. Your eyes stream with tears and you cough into your hand. Presently you realize that the group are watching you with sidelong glances. A low chuckle echoes through the group. The elf who offered you the cup now grins at you, and communicates with broken words, "You drink welcoming. Good coming to Deep Dark..." You nod, and feel the strange brew going to your head. But this is not just the dizzy hum of wine or mead. Your very sight is changing! You turn your eyes to the stone walls, and they are not inert. They are slow and careful workers, grinding and pushing to make gold out of dross. You see the Dark Elves that surround you, and through their feet and hands the slow life-blood of this realm ripples and pulses like a thick taut rope, thrumming with tension and life. It is the living patience of the realm of deep stone. It is brooding and beautiful. THE EITR OF SVARTALFHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. You turn to the assembled elves, and by slow and careful conversation learn of the mine you've entered: The Dvergr rule here, and the Dark Elves work. The mine is dangerous for many reasons, some of them alive and with a taste for blood. The mines are many leagues deep, and you would do well to find a guide. No, they will not be the guide - their work calls to them. By and by, they wish you well and rise to return to their work. You take your leave with the comforting knowledge that in this realm, as in Midgard, some things never change. [[DAY 10->DAY 10SN]]<h2>NORTH - The Deep Mines</h2> You turn your ship into the currents, and make it fast to a mooring stake on the shore. Then you set your feet to the great road that leads deeper into the earth. Shafts and hovels stretch off from this great artery in every direction, as it winds slowly downwards into the heart of the stone. You pass many workers as you proceed along the sloping path. Most are Dark Elves - tall well-muscled figures with bent backs, who keep their heads low, and avoid eye contact. They go about their business with the weight of weariness upon them, and answer your questions in short uninitelligible single syllables. The Dvergr are fewer in number, but very obviously the dominant peoples in this place. They are smaller in stature, but barrel-chested and straight-backed, and their clothes and adornments are of finer make. They glare at you with open hostility. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9SN]]The soldiers encircle you, and the surrounding workers turn and watch, clearly happy for the distraction of an unfolding battle. The closest of your attackers races forward with a loud bellow, hoping to catch you off guard! You raise your shield and bring your (print:$weapon) to bear... ROLL A D20 TO ATTACK! [[NOPE, THAT DEFINITELY WASN'T IT...->DAY 21E]]You raise the glass to your lips. The smell makes your eyes water, and the liquid moves like molasses. This is poison, and you are no fool. You mime tasting of it, and replace the watersking where you found it. PRUDENCE IS THE BETTER PART OF VALOR: YOU NEITHER GAIN NOR LOSE A DIE IN YOUR INSPIRATION POOL. The craftsman who lent it to you eyes you suspiciously, but says nothing. You try by careful conversation to glean some knowledge of this realm from your acquaintance, but he is reluctant. You seem to have offended him somehow. By persistence you learn that this place is called Nidavellir. The Dvergr rule here, led by Mótsognir, First and Most Ancient of their kind. The work that comes from here is theirs. Their pride in it is great, and they guard their secrets jealously. The Dark Elves work the mines and serve them. No, they will not help or guide you, but if your purpose is as great as you seem to think, you should find someone else to talk to who has time and patience to talk to about it. It becomes obvious you are unwelcome, so you take your leave... (link: "Continue")[ You continue threading your way through the forges and worktables of Nidavellir, though the air becomes thick and heavy with dry acrid dust. You cough and sputter, leaning against a nearby wall. It is as if you are attempting to breathe underwater. Then in an instant, the air is not so foul to you. You open your eyes, and find that your very sight has changed as well! You turn your eyes to the stone walls, and they are not inert. They are slow and careful workers, grinding and pushing to make gold out of dross. You see the Dark Elves that surround you, and through their feet and hands the slow life-blood of this realm ripples and pulses like a thick taut rope, thrumming with tension and life. It is the living patience of the realm of deep stone. It is brooding and beautiful. THE EITR OF SVARTALFHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES! [[DAY 10->DAY 10SS]] ]You raise the waterskin to your lips. The contents moves like molasses, and its taste is like ash and fire. Out of courtesy to your host, you take a swig and replace it where it was. Your eyes stream with tears and you cough into your hand. Presently you realize that several of the nearby smiths and craftsmen are watching, grinning at your discomfort. A low chuckle floats on the air. The Dvergr craftsman grins, and speaks with a thick heavy accent, "Welcome to the Forges of Nidavellir, Maor. Your kind haven't been seen in this realm in long ages." You nod, and feel the strange brew going to your head. But this is not just the dizzy hum of wine or mead. Your very sight is changing... You turn your eyes to the stones of the floor, and they are not inert. They grind slowly and inevitably like great colossae, pushing and flexing to make gold out of dross. You see the Dvergr that surround you, and through their feet and hands the slow life-blood of this realm ripples and pulses like a thick taut rope, thrumming with tension and life. It is the living patience of the realm of deep stone. It is brooding and beautiful. THE EITR OF SVARTALFHEIM DWELLS IN YOUR BLOOD AND YOUR BONES. (link:'Continue')[ You turn to your audience, and by slow and careful conversation begin to learn of the great crafting floor upon which you stand: The Dvergr rule here, and the work that comes from here is theirs. Their pride in it is great, and they guard their secrets jealously. The Dark Elves work the mines and serve them. No, they will not be the guide - their work calls to them, but if your purpose is as great as you seem to think, you should seek audience with Mótsognir, First of the Dvergr. By and by, they wish you well with laughter at your strange ways, and rise to return to their work. You take your leave with the comforting knowledge that in this realm, as in Midgard, some things never change. [[DAY 10->DAY 10SS]] ]<h2>SOUTH - Nidavellir, The Dark Fields</h2> You turn your ship into the currents, and moor it in the great huddle of laden transports along the dock. The mast and sails of your ship jut skyward in odd juxtaposition to the crafts surrounding it, and you realize they serve no purpose here. There is no wind to speak of, just the heavy air of the underground. Then you turn your eyes to the endless forges and workfloors that stretch out before you, wondering where in this maze you might find what you seek... [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9SS]]Suddenly and everywhere the voice of Odin rings, as it did in your head a scant few days ago. "Stay your hand, Dvergr! This one is here by my hand, and should you harm him I will reave the life from you where you stand. You will take him to Mostognir and give him leave to speak. This is our will." And with that his voice is gone. But what remains is a nimbus of soft white light that clings to you like a beacon. The assembled soldiers are stunned to silence. Finally the one in command gives mumbled orders and the company forms a silent escort. Any questions from you are met with sidelong glances of fear. After endless hours of ascending tunnels, giving way to well-worn roads, then bustling city streets, you come to a mighty fortress, carved into the stone of Svartalfheim. Marching gives way to waiting, as you are interviewed by soldiers and bureaucrafts of increasing authority. None is willing to take responsibility for a glowing human, so by and by you find yourself awaiting audience with the ruler of this realm: Mostognir himself. KEEP THE DIE (A D12) FROM TODAY FOR YOUR INSPIRATION POOL - ODIN'S PRESENCE IS WITH YOU! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 13->DAY 13S]]Suddenly and everywhere the voice of Odin rings like a thunderclap, and there is a blinding flash of light! "Stay your hand, Dvergr worm! This one is here by my hand, and should you harm him I will reave the life from you where you stand. You will take him to Mótsognir and give him leave to speak. I am the All-Father and this is my will!" And with that his voice is gone, but what remains is a nimbus of soft white light that clings to you like a beacon. There is a stunned silence, before the crowd scatters in fear. The commander sheaths his dagger and mutters something about taking you into custody, but he will not meet your eyes. The company forms a silent escort. Any questions from you are met with sidelong glances of fear. Several hours of marching pass and you see much of the city as you do. Markets give way to forges, then to walled estates, and arched tunnels, all carved from the mighty rock of Svartalfheim. The city is dizzying in its expanse. Marching gives way to waiting, as you are interviewed by soldiers and bureaucrafts of increasing authority. None is willing to take responsibility for a glowing human, so by and by you find yourself awaiting audience with the ruler of this realm: Mostognir himself. KEEP THE DIE (A D12) FROM TODAY FOR YOUR INSPIRATION POOL - ODIN'S PRESENCE IS WITH YOU! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 13->DAY 13S]]Suddenly and everywhere the voice of Odin rings like a thunderclap, and there is a blinding flash of light! "Stay your hand, Dvergr worm! This one is here by my hand, and should you harm him I will reave the life from you where you stand. You will take him to Mótsognir and give him leave to speak. I am the All-Father and this is my will!" And with that his voice is gone, but what remains is a nimbus of soft white light that clings to you like a beacon. There is a stunned silence, before the crowd scatters in fear. The commander sheaths his dagger and mutters something about taking you into custody, but he will not meet your eyes. Reluctantly, the assembled soldiers gather, and form a cold and silent escort. Any questions are rebuffed with silence are grunts of indifference. Several hours of marching pass and you see much of the city as you do. Markets give way to forges, then to walled estates, and arched tunnels, all carved from the mighty rock of Svartalfheim. The city is dizzying in its expanse. Marching gives way to waiting, as you are interviewed by soldiers and bureaucrafts of increasing authority. None is willing to take responsibility for a glowing human, so by and by you find yourself awaiting audience with the ruler of this realm: Mostognir himself. KEEP THE DIE (A D12) FROM TODAY FOR YOUR INSPIRATION POOL - ODIN'S PRESENCE IS WITH YOU! [[CONTINUE TO DAY 13->DAY 13S]]As you are roughly gathered up by the troop of soldiers, you cry out in protest! But before your cry can register, a far greater voice rings out suddenly and everywhere - the voice of Odin! "Stay your hand, Dvergr! I am Odin All-Father, and this one is here by my hand, and should you harm him I will reave the life from each of you where you stand! You will take him to Mostognir and give him leave to speak. This is our will!" And with that his voice is gone. But in its absence, a dull nimbus of light suffuses your body - the mark of the divine upon you! The Dvergr present are stunned into terrified silence for a long moment. Hastily, they return your belongings to you, and without making eye contact escort you for several hours through layers of a great city into a mighty hall, cloven with magnificent workmanship from the bedrock of this realm. This is the Fortress of Mostognir. Marching gives way to waiting, as you are interviewed by soldiers and bureaucrafts of increasing authority. None is willing to take responsibility for a glowing human, so by and by you find yourself awaiting audience with the ruler of this realm: Mostognir himself. Your eyes stream with tears and you cough into your hand. Presently you realize that all heads are turned to you, smiling at your discomfort. A low chuckle floats on the air. The Dvergr proprietor grins, and communicates with a thick heavy accent, "Welcome to Hamarsskor, Maor. Your kind haven't been seen in long ages." You nod, and feel the strange brew going to your head. But this is not just the dizzy hum of wine or mead. Your very sight is changing... You turn your eyes to the stones of the floor, and they are not inert. They grind slowly and inevitably like great collossae, pushing and flexing to make gold out of dross. [[DAY 10->DAY 10SWY]]<h2>WEST - The City of Hamarsskor</h2> You moor your ship in the great huddle of laden transports along the dock. Its mast and sails jut skyward in odd juxtaposition to the crafts surrounding it, and you realize they serve no purpose here. There is no wind to speak of, just the heavy air of the underground. You turn and enter the bustling streets before you. Most of the peoples here are Dvergr. They are smaller in stature, but barrel-chested and straight-backed, and their clothes and adornments are generally of finer make. They glare at you with varying degrees of suspicion. Those who are not Dvergr are Dark Elves - tall well-muscled figures with bent backs, who keep their heads low, and avoid eye contact. They go about their business with the weight of weariness upon them, and converse in short uninitelligible single syllables. [[CONTINUE TO DAY 9->Day 9SW]]<h2>THE WOLF</h2> "This is Ylgr, my she-wolf. She will show you the way to Ymir's body, and aid you in undoing Sigyn's madness." Ylgr stalks from the halls behind you and sits, regarding you with knowing eyes. She is beautiful and terrible in her stillness, and the Eitr flows around her as an adornment of royalty. ADD A REROLL ON ANY DIE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Ylgr") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16ST]]<h2>THE WOLF</h2> A mighty wolf stares back at you with knowing eyes. She is beautiful and terrible in her stillness, and the Eitr flows around her as an adornment of royalty. You stay frozen in place, scarcely daring to breathe, but the great wolf makes no hostile move. Instead she turns away down the dark street, then looks back at you expectantly. You know this beast from the elders' stories: This is Ylgr, she-wolf protector of Svartalfheim. With her as your companion, Mostognir's wrath cannot touch you. This is blessing indeed! ADD A REROLL ON ANY DICE ROLL TO YOUR INSPIRATION POOL! (set: $animal to "Ylgr") [[CONTINUE TO DAY 16->DAY 16ST]]<h2>THE WOLF</h2> A mighty wolf surrounded by a nimbus of glowing light leaps through the crowd, bowling over the assembled soldiers to stand over you, teeth bared. She snarls and growls with terrible rage. The Dvergr flee in abject terror, and in mere moments the streets are deserted, save for you and the great wolf. You crawl slowly away from the wolf, hands raised, but the great beast makes no hostile move. Instead, she stares back at you with knowing eyes. She is beautiful and terrible in her stillness, and the Eitr flows around her as an adornment of royalty. Abruptly, she turns away down the dark street, then looks back at you expectantly. You know this beast from the elders' stories: This is Ylgr, she-wolf protector of Svartalfheim. With her as your companion, Mostognir's wrath cannot touch you. This is blessing indeed! [[CONTINUE->ScyllaDMG]]<h2>DEFEAT!</h2> You've wounded the creature greviously, but not mortally, and it knows it has you now. It leers at you menacingly, and as its fist descends, your vision narrows and fades to black. But you do not die, and even the deep and visceral pain you should feel clears like mist at the dawn in merest moment. But no sun rise comes. Instead, you are spinning and falling endlessly down and down and down - the colors of the worlds mix and mingle as you tumble for what seems an eternity. And then you are not falling, you are sinking in a mire that pulls at your boots and clings to your skin like the touch of the dead. And all around you stretch the endless windswept wastelands. You rise, and while the fearsome wounds from your combat are still present, they are as far-away reminders of a fading nightmare. The blood that should be coursing from them is frozen in time, like a winter stream. What is this place? (link: "Continue")[The mud near you coalesces like fingers grasping at the air, growing and congealing towards the shape of a body. The runnels of muck resolve into features, first vague, then clear and alive. Then an arm reaches out from it, becoming a tendril, that wraps with the inevitability of a snake's coils around your neck. A face emerges and turns to you - the face of a goddess: beautiful and hollow and terrible. A voice like a final whisper permeates your mind, ""Who are you, and what business have you in the realm of the dead?" It does not possess a visible mouth or teeth, instead, it latches onto its victim and begins to drain their warmth, growing larger and more solid with every degree of temperature it steals. You draw a shaky breath. The battle is over. You've won! (link: "Continue")[ But no sooner have the waters settled from the battle, than a great ship bears down on yours from the horizon. It comes abreast of you and from far above, a crew of Jotunheim giants call down to you. "Who are you, and why do you trouble this realm!" You stand and call out, "I come by the will of Odin and His Beloved, with a purpose greater than any one man or giant. You would do well to aid me or leave me be!" The gathered giants give a rough chuckle and advance on you. "The names of Odin and Frigga carry no weight here, manling..." [[CONTINUE->JOT1]] ]You are filled with wariness, as the flickering image of the God Loki stands before you, chained and writhing even as he speaks. The venom of the serpent above him drips, momentarily searing, then evaporating in a hiss. Around his throat, the shackles of his binding gleam with cruel, cold light. "I know of your quest, Maor," he hisses, a raw laugh catching in his throat, "and while it pains me to admit it, my interests align with yours and with that great fool in the sky. If all is destroyed then I will not survive to enjoy my revenge at Ragnarok..." "I will lend you my blessing. Go with the cunning of the snake as your ally! It will teach your hand to find the hidden weakness, and turn events to your benefit, when you have need of it." And around your neck appears a thin, carved amulet of a snake with emerald eyes. Its touch burns you like a goad, urging you forth, but you feel the power it imbues to you as well. A mixed blessing indeed... Then his form shifts and fades, and as it does, you hear a distant mischevious chuckle, and the parting words of Loki: "Fair winds, Warrior!" "Odin, my father, has told me of your quest, Maor," he says, his voice steady and quiet as snow falling on earth, "And it will test you mightily. Go with my blessing! It will steady your hand and be a well of stillness to you when your focus wavers." And he places around your neck a snowflake wrought of shining steel, that is his symbol. It draws in the light and rests heavy and cool against your chest. Then he steps aside and gestures to your waiting ship. "It is time - the All-Father will soon open the way to the Bifrost. Make ready, and watch for horizon to split. Fair winds, Warrior!"
